Great spot. It's in the sleepy-yet-hip Noe Valley.

We made reservations using open table and that was easy.  We were given a few choices and an email. Also received an email and text message reminding us of our reservation.  

Once we entered it was like being transported to an "off the beaten path" Italian restaurant in Italy.   We were greeted with the typical "Buonasera".  We were brought water and our drink orders were taken and in front of us in no time.

Even though it was a very busy Saturday night the service didn't let that on at all.  It was perfect.

Our order:

CROSTINO (Eggplant mousse, hazelnuts, burrata)
This was incredible.  Flavorful, fresh and fancy!  Then again we are suckers for burrata!  

POLPETTE (Slowly braised homemade Tuscan baby meatballs)
These (3) mouthwatering meatballs were incredible.  Sauce was just right.

PAPPARDELLE (Home made wide fettuccine Sonoma rabbit sugo) 1/2  order
Perfectly cooked pasta and flavorful rabbit pieces.  Delicious.

TAGLIATELLE (Homemade chestnut pasta, wild boar ragu') 1/2  order
Wild boar chunks, pasta was cooked to perfection as well.

RIGATONI  (Tube pasta, tomato, cream, home made sausage, roasted red peppers and peas)
Simple and straightforward.  And awesome.

VITELLO (Breaded scaloppine, prosciutto, mozzarella, onions)
Best scaloppine I've had in a very long, long time.  The onions surprise you... just weren't expecting this explosion of flavor.  Great job!

MEDAGLIONI (Sauteed beef tenderloin medallions, truffle sauce)
Order this medium-rare and it was.  Truffle sauce was divine. 

We had ZERO room for dessert. :(  Gelato and Sorbet ordered by the couple "next door" looked great and when asked, they loved it.

I had an espresso and it was great.  

Hope you enjoy your meal as much as we did.


Update: I was in town on a business trip and made the quick drive to my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. 

Awesome service and awesome food.  The vermicelli was inspired and the lentil soup was just like nonna's recipe from the old country. 

Please stop here.  It will be worth it.
author: Raul R.

description: Classically simple dishes that never get tired. If you want some dressed up comfort food this place is for you.
author: Fred P.

description: The lasagna is delicious! Had that as my entree. The area was very quiet and had a romantic setting. Started out with just the bread. Came with a pesto type of dip. Was great.
author: Anna D.

description:
Great atmosphere, perfect service, great food.

I came here with an old friend for some good old fashioned Italian comfort food on a cold San Francisco night and we were not disappointed. The waiter was friendly and knowledgeable, and helped me select a good wine after my frist selection was sold out. 

We ordered 2 appetizers to share, a salad and thinly sliced beef with salad. Both were superb, and the salad included chunks of fine cheese and cubes of panchetta. The beef was something like dried coppa. 

For the main course we shared some rigatoni with meat sauce and a filet of bread veal. Both were absolutely superb, and they said the rigatoni recipe was the same they've been making for 15 years. 

FOr dessert we were pretty stuffed so we just got tea and espresso. A perfect experience, no complaints, great food, excellent service.
author: Jordan C.

description: Food was delicious! Service was excellent. I came here for a birthday dinner with my friends, and we had a blast and nearly had to be rolled outta there because we were so full!
author: Kassi K.

description:
This place is an extremely solid neighborhood Italian. The only things I can say is that 1.) Service was just adequate and 2.) Food delivered to expectations, but nothing exceeded.

Appetizers:

-Meatballs were just okay, maybe even below average. But the sauce was delicious and flavorful.
-Crostini was good, but nothing to write home about.
-Baby Octopus... didn't try it, but the table didn't seem to swoon over them.

Entrees:

-Appreciate that you can do a "Appetizer" sized pasta order for your entree. It allowed us to try a couple more things on the menu.
-Pasta dishes were creative and tasty. Everything was well prepared and done to a professionally and technically sound level.

Desserts:

-Tiramisu was just okay. Ladyfingers were overly soaked and there was just a bit too much espresso flavor.
-Apple tart was delicious and pretty much a perfect dessert
-Panna Cotta was done pretty well... a little too stiff, but the buttermilk was a nice touch to this variation
author: Arick R.

description: Wow!  I had the perfect dining experience.  The weather, the night, the food, the service, the wine...everything came together perfectly at Bacco's.   The dinning experience was right out of Italy.  We were not rushed.  There was never a feeling that "your 90-minutes are up, now get out because we need this table."  We savored the polpette (meatballs) while enjoying our wine and perusing our dinner options.  For dinner, the gnocchi are must, but so is the brasato (braised short ribs).  Add a side of cavoletti (brussel sprouts) and/or the fagiolini (string beans), a nice bottle of wine and you will feel transported to one of the little restaurants in one of those little towns that dot the Italian country side.
author: Beth V.

description: Great neighborhood spot. Dinner and appetizers well prepared, great presentation and ingredients. Perfect service. Corkage on the high side, else a 5 star review.
author: Tim C.

description: Love love love love love. I cannot say enough good things about this place. My boyfriend grew up around the corner and is treated like family every time he comes in even if its months (or years!) apart. They are friendly, warm, and both casual and classy. The food is amazing- calamari, pastas, desserts, great wines. A huge PLUS- the only gluten free options in the city for italian that I love. They import their corn pasta from italy and I get so excited everytime I get to go there and actually tuck into a plate of pasta with wonderfully fresh toppings and prepared so lovingly. Thanks Bacco!
author: jeddie k.

description: Yummy! Great Xmas eve dinner-You have NEVER had gnocchi this light!
author: Mary F.

description:
Delicious 5-star eating experience--I just ate there but feel the need to write on it right away! Great service, great ambiance, great cute neighborhood too! Here's the run-down:

-Great wine list--we asked them to recommend a Melbec and it was a great addition to the meal

Starters:
I should also note that we were going to split everything and they brought out 3 separated plates for each item we ordered--so wonderful!

Potato leek soup 9.50-

Organic beet salad with orange and goat cheese in a honey citrus dressing $12--delicious and fresh ingredients--the dressing was just light enough and the goat cheese was perfection

Sauteed Brussels Sprouts, with olive oil and pancetta $9--I'm not a huge brussel sprouts fan, but the pancetta made the difference

Sauteed beef tenderloin medallions, truffle sauce $28--THIS was the highlight of the meal! We got the beef medium-rare and it was cooked perfectly--so tender and delicious. Came with some mashed potatoes which were amazing as well as some veggies and we even devoured those! The truffle sauce, like any other truffle sauce, was also absolutely amazing! Highly recommend this as a must-get!

RISOTTO
Made to order Vialone Nano simmered with imported Italian black truffles $30.00-- Apparently we were on a truffle train and ordered this special of the day--it takes a little extra time to come out but we were having great conversation so we didn't mind--they also brought it out at the same time as the beef dish so it was very complementary! 

Dessert:Puff pastry apple tart with vanilla gelato and caramel sauce--The puff pastry was amazingly---well, puffy.... but warm and delicious and there was a slight and very subtle hint of ginger in it that really made it unique--it was a great day to end the meal!
author: An-Nhien L.

description: Excellent spicy bucatini with bacon and pecorino.  Very good meal. Loved the menu options.
author: Tony K.

description: It's one of those local restaurants that could easily be a destination restaurant. The food is stellar, the environment is classy, the staff are attentive and extremely familial. Added bonus: they've had a Michelin nod and serve gluten free pasta options.
author: David L.

description:
Solid Italian food in Noe.

You can go a step down in price and a step up in taste by going to Lupa right nearby, but Bacco is a solid option. One benefit is they do half plates of pasta which are great for sharing.
author: Mike G.

description:
The service was excellent from the time we walked in until the time we left , I especially loved the romantic atmosphere. The menu selection was great especially since I can be a very picky eater,I chose the fettucini
noodles with baby shrimp, arugula, with a nice light sauce. I will be returning to eat here again and also recommend this restaurant to my friends and family.
author: shaundra b.

description: it can be a bit more expensive but this is a cute little restaurant at the edge of noe valley.  Its nice without being pretentious.  The food and wine was delicious and if you're lucky you can sit by one of the giant windows that line the restaurant.
author: Elaine G.

description:
The house-made squid ink Tonnarelli was cooked al dente, and had such a subtle umami to it, including a very startling color.  The iodine from the ink of the infused square shaped spaghetti yields a bit of a mild sea taste to it, and the pieces of spicy calamari and tomato adds even more depth of flavor to the entire dish -overall a very alluring flavor profile.

The gnocchi dumplings came out piping hot, flavored with beet but very ecru colored in appearance, was simply topped with gorgonzola cheese, and toasted hazelnuts.  The warmth of this dish left me a little starry-eyed, so creamy, delicious, and wholesome.  The half order, was the perfect amount for sharing amongst our table of three, along with the string beans which were sautéed to a tender crisp, and topped with rich spicy tomato sauce.

The slices of the grilled bavette steak Tagliata were delicious, and the medium-rare doneness was point-on: the sides well browned, and warm through the middle with just a hint of red.  And served with a thin crispy sheet of Italian flatbread / Pane Carasau.  

Great service, Quiet location, and extremely fresh food.
author: Ty T.

description: Hidden gem in Noe. Had probably the best piece of lasagne in my life. Tomato salad was outstanding. Homemade bread. Family run. No pretense, just great authentic Italian food.
author: Jason M.

description: I will return. An off the main drag treasure.
author: Jim C.

description: Heard this was a neighborhood gem and we went there last night.  It was terrific!  The dining room feels authentic Italian and the waiter's thick Italian accent made it difficult to understand the specials - so I knew the food was going to be amazing!!!  Lived in Noe for 6 years and had never been there - def a big mistake. I had the beet salad with arugula, then the rigatoni, and a wonderful glass of Sangiovese.  I will be back for more.
author: Marlon S.

description: Enjoyed my meal here, but more importantly, I LOVED the service here. One of the friendliest waiters I've seen.
author: J L.

description:
Simply terrific food and service.

Appetizers.....grilled squid......calamari.......meat balls, all quickly devoured.       Calamari different than the usual, my least favorite of the 3.
Mains....involtini.......veal wrapped around spinach, cheese and eggplant....2 thumbs up.     Lasagna......wonderful .  Risotto special of the day was just that......very very special.........angel hair pasta with meat balls and a tomato sauce from heaven.
Coffees and deserts to cap the dinner were super ........and a great Barolo wine completed the meal.     

I will be back
author: Murray O.

description:
(See pics)

As fate would have it, I am at this part of the town, that Ed. U mentioned Bacco a couple weeks ago, and I trekked and walked off a few calories before arriving at this place.

I immediately like this place for its home feel, warm and welcoming restaurant.

For starter, I had BACCO salad which had fresh wild arugola, radicchio, roasted walnuts, gorgonzola cheese mixed with balsamic dressing. I like the light style of salad. The bread with pesto oil was also very good that I had to pace myself.

For the main course, I really wanted risotto and some seafood and they were super nice enough to make a special dish for me. The made to order Carnaroli risotto was very tasty with the light tomato sauce. The abundance of tasty seafood-- clams, mussels, scallops, fish and shrimps! The dish was rich, tasteful with very generous portions.

I also had a glass of 2008 Falanghina which was a good recommendation and they poured more than 1 glass.

I was too full to have any dessert but they were so sweet and served a complimentary Zibibbo! Such a sweet ending to a great evening.

Service was very very friendly and nice. They made you feel like home with fantastic service. Love the ambiance, people and the great food.

Food is a definite 4 stars of quality with 5 stars of quantity and also, the 5 great stars for the service.
author: T L.

description: Can't believe I didn't write a review a long time ago! As an SF native I am happy and proud this place is still around and keeps getting better and better over the years! I have been going here since I was 13 years old. I am now 27 and this place is still one if not thee best Italian restaurants that's not a chain in SF. The Rigatoni is my absolute favorite!!! I had my 25th Bday dinner here and it was the best dinner and dinner experience I've ever had. They reserved the back room for me and let me choose from a few options for my pre fixed menu and all my guest LOVED it. :) The owner is super nice and always has good staff for awesome service. As an SF native I am happy and proud this place is still around and keeps getting better and better over the years!
author: Monica L.

description:
I've been going to Bacco for 2 1/2 years and each time I never had a bad meal. From the soup to the salad my mouth watered between every bit. The food is outstanding they have a new chef that is even better than the Chef before and if I could give this place 6 stars I would not to mention the owner is very hands on in this restaurant and couldn't be nicer to me and my husband. Each time we eat here is always fun, Exciting and the food is exceptional. Bacco is what you call authentic fine Italian Cuisine.

Favorite Cuisines:
-Slowly braised beef and Gnocchi so tendered and falls right off the bone
-Risotto with Prawns creamy and rich and the prawns are crispy and juicy with a nice grill crisp taste

Favorite Desserts: 
-Gluten free Flour less cake is velvety, Moist, And just delicious.
-Myer lemon curd in a butter crust is sweet and tangy and the crust was flaky and crisp to perfection
author: Annikka M.

description:
I chose this place for the gluten free bread and the reviews about the GF food.  I was tired of going to italian restaurants and not being able to eat, along with my companions,  the delicious bread they bring out before dinner.  
The GF bread was SO disappointing.  (Udi's store-bought sandwich bread would've been a better alternative to what was offered) That being said, my companion said the regular bread was delicious.
The meatballs I had were very very good, and it was a nice change to be able to eat them for once, as most meatballs contain gluten. 
My companion ordered the risotto and it had a great flavor but a slightly liquid-y texture.  It was average. 
Overall, the place was not terrible and the staff were incredibly nice, but in my opinion, the restaurant was incredibly overpriced for the portion sizes and the quality of the food. Three $$$ for SURE!
author: Erin J.

description:
Fine Italian dining with gluten-free options!
The food was good and the atmosphere nice.
For the gluten intolerant, it is a godsend.  Otherwise,
I'd call it average.  The fact that they they have gluten-free
gnocchi is amazing.  If found it a bit chewy for my taste but
hey, I haven't been able to eat gnocchi for 10 years now so
I wasn't complaining.  The arugula and fennel that came
with my wife's chicken was fantastic while the black kale
from the contorni section of the menu was a bit tough.
author: Steve M.

description:
I was a bit worried about going to an Italian Restaurant on Valentine's Day because I didn't want us to get too full to be uncomfortable later doing what couples are supposed to do on Valentines Day (watch Valentines episodes on Nick at Night--get your minds out of the gutter people).

We started with the Salmon Appetizer and the Beef Salad. Both were delicious, especially the salmon.

For our main courses we both had mini shell spaghetti with a red sauce and sausage. It was the perfect amount of food--filling but not bloating. The only "turn off" was when my sweetie said "these shells kind of look like maggots".

I wanted to try the dessert because it looked SO good--a light apple tart with a fantastic crust, strips of apple and gelato with a very light ginger taste. I learned long ago that whenever my honey says "I don't want dessert" it really means "I'll just pick at yours". It's an annoying habit, but it was Valentine's Day so I kept my mouth shut. I didn't want to wreck my chances of getting to watch Nick at Night :).

Can't wait to go back here again for their normal menu, which looks scrumptious.

PS. Yes, I did get to watch Nick at Night--twice!
author: John R.

description:
My husband and I had a lovely New Year's Eve dinner here. The service was very courteous, and the ambiance intimate. 

The quality of food was not aligned with the cost,I would say. We had the lamb and the lasagna which were both ok. One thing which was amazing was the tiramisu. 

All in all, I would go back for a light lunch and dessert, but not for a nicer dinner. It was way too expensive for the quality served.
author: Romina T.

description: Ristorante Bacco is a good fit when it comes to special events such as graduations, weddings, birthdays, etc. This is my favorite destination when I have a date and I am trying to show off and impress the occasional partner (so fat they have never made me look bad). The staff members know me well and they always do something special during my dinner (bring an amuse, drink, etc).The food is great, better than the restaurants in the area. Most of the time I either order the calamari or the octopus to start my dinner. Some of my favorite main courses are Gnochi, Risotto, Tagliatele and Rigatoni (I think among those Gnochi is my very favorite one). They also have a good wine selection, including different kinds of Chiantis, Montepuccianos and Cabernets. I do not know what else to say, I just like this place a lot.
author: Marcos F.

description:
I've been here twice so far, and will most likely be returning.

My sister took me during the winter and I took my mom for mother's day.

My mom would give this place 5 stars for sure, her opinion of the place is that it's very italian.  She over ordered, got an appetizer, pasta, and main dish.  These are not small portions folks!

I had gluten free pasta both times.  The way the pasta was cooked was perfect, each time...and I'm a fan of consistency.  I was even brought gluten free house made bread to dip into olive oil....this could be worked on, the bread was  'eh ok'...although I SUPER appreciate the effort!

Do not be in a rush if you come here...it's quality...and just order a glass of wine and bring good company and be happy.

One note of gluten free improvement:  have more dessert options for the gluten free crowd on the menu.  If there were a weekends only special like, let's say, tiramisu...ummm I'd be there A LOT
author: Q L.

description:
Decided to go to Bacco as a friend currently is currently avoiding Gluten and Bacco has various options.  

1) Bread and Dipping Sauce - the gluten free bread was moist and very good.  The dipping sauce looked like pesto, but tasted fishy which was weird.  When we inquired, we found out that it was made with Anchovies.  It was not to our liking, but part of it may have been due to the surprise factor

2) Wine - 1/2 bottle of the Soave.  Tasty, decent price.  No complaints

3) Gluten Free Meatballs - they were tasty, but were served at room temperature.  Would much rather had them warm.  

4) Brussel sprouts - they were rather tasty, but the meat that came with them just made the dish look unappealing.  Large cubes and they were rather tough, but tasted good.  Would suggest going with more like bacon bits so that you can have little pieces with each bite of sprout.

5) Gluten Free Gnocci - this dish was ok.  They were dense, which is not the style I like.  Not bad, but not a dish we would be excited to order again

6) TAGLIATELLE - started without the parmesan and the dish was flat.  The boar ragu had little flavor.  Even after getting the parmesan and pepper and adding salt, it was under seasoned.  

7) Vanilla Ice Cream with Espresso - I am not a coffee drinker and this dish started out great.  The warm and cold mixture really was something that I really liked.  However, after the espresso cooled and mixed with the ice cream completely, the dish started to loose its flavor.

I really dont want to give this a 2 star, as it wasn't terrible, but yelp does say that 2 is "I have experienced better".  I always look for the would I order that again factor when reviewing dishes and a restaurant.  I cant say that any of the dishes as they were served would compel me to order them again or want to come back.

Really a shame as when we came and learned about all the gluten free options, we were really hoping that this would be a big success and get us to drive across town to eat here frequently.
author: Markus S.

description: I'm temporarily living close to this restaurant so I have eaten here a couple times recently. It is solidly tasty traditional Italian food. I've enjoyed the arugula salad and squid ink pasta as well as grilled calamari with white beans and also the lentil soup. The service is efficient and attentive, the ambiance clean and inviting, and often the friendly owner is there to greet you, which is always nice as a restaurant patron.
author: Sandy G.

description: Food is excellent and the service very attentive.  I had the Ravioli and it was awesome! And the desserts are to die for. Flourless Chocolate cake is my fave.   Love that this restaurant is just steps from home.
author: Joan K.

description:
First time I ordered gnocchi.  I love butternut squash so I ordered the butternut squash gnocchi with sage butter and hazelnut.  It had great flavor but it was a little sticky and doughy.  It was too glutenous for me.  I'm not convinced that I will like gnocchi or will ever order it again.

Salted cod with polenta.  I was hoping to get pan fried polenta rather than mushy blob.  I should've asked.   The cod which was on top of the polenta was really salty. Go figure "salted".  Still it would have been nice to have maybe toast to balance out the saltiness and mushiness.  A lesson learned.  Ask before ordering.

My favorite was the capellini with meatballs.  The marinara sauce was on the sour side but the meatballs were tasty and delicious and the capellini was cooked al dente.  I also got my veggies for the day with the side of brussels sprouts & pancetta.

I didn't like the dessert which was chocolate ice cream sandwiches.  The cookies had a dried up brownie texture and they were too sweet. Also there was hardly any ice cream between the cookies.  

Service was prompt and attentive almost to point of rushing.
author: Hannah C.

description:
What a charming find!  Went here with my parents but i'll definitely be back with friends (or a date).  The food was delicious without being pretentious.  Our waiter was great and made the perfect suggestions on what wine to pair with our dishes, which I always find helpful.

I definitely recommend the grilled calamari and the tagliatelle.  Also, HUGE props for having so many gluten free dishes!  My mother is gluten free and she adored the gnocchi and the gluten free bread.  Perfect family dinner, and as lovely as the places I saw during my last vacation to Italy.
author: Carmen K.

description: Great restaurant! Great food! Great people! I played violin here for a wedding reception and enjoyed every minute. The waiters and waitresses were very accommodating and always enthusiastic. The food was delicious as well! I've never had prosciutto that has been aged for 24 months! So delicate and savory. If I wasn't a student at UC Berkeley, I'd come here all the time for the cozy environment and good company. Thanks so much, Bacco!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Great italian place in Noe Valley. I came here with my family...NO reservation...last Saturday night, and they were just able to accommodate us. They have a big menu with a lot of amazing dishes. We were told they were known for risotto, so we got that for the table, along with their braised meatballs and Buratta with eggplant mousse...all very good.

Entrees were great also, they do magical things with fish and pasta. The atmosphere is intimate and comfortable, and the wait staff is very knowledgeable and attentive. Overall one of the top italian restaurants I have been to in SF!
author: John P.

description: It was my first time visiting San Francisco. I told my sister I wanted to try an Italian restaurant. We went to Lupa but it was closed. We arrived to Bacco and I tried the "Fregola" entree. It had a very strong oceany flavor. Moreover, I did not sent my plate back. When the manager came back to clear our plates, I offered my feedback. She acted in a defensive manner. She raised her voice stating "This is my best selling dish and we bought everything today, I can show you the receipt" she also mentioned "I will take it out of the bill but certainly you do not eat seafood." I did not want her to take it off my bill but she stormed out. I have lived in Chicago for years and I love Italian food and seafood. I have been at great restaurants such as Nico Osteria that is well known for fresh products and never had a problem. The food was nothing special but the attitude of the manager was unacceptable. Kudos for the male server that was very nice.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Spacious, quiet restaurant.  Located off the main drag, it offers a windowed view of the neighborhood.  The food was spectacular.  Of the appetizers, the calamari was my favorite. (Visit their website, and it's pictured.)  The polpette and crostino can easily fill you up, so please plan on sharing!  I ordered the tonnorelli (squid ink pasta).  The sauce can truly define the dish, and this dish is a must have.  Save room for dessert and try their tiramisu.  Very light, it disappeared off the plate rather too quickly.

I will say too how child-friendly the restaurant is -- or should I say child accepting.  Much like restaurants in Italy, the bambino is doted on and part of the dinner party.  Equivalent restaurants in Los Angeles would frown upon bringing babies to dinner, but Bacco was very accommodating.
author: Marichelle M.

description:
So if it weren't for the service and the ambiance, this place would barely be a one restaurant. We went there Friday night after reading the Yelp reviews--I was excited. I love Italian food--I love Noe Valley--so why wouldn't I try a nice little Italian place with my lovely wife there?

We arrived early, around 5:30, and it as quiet, just my wife and I and an older couple. Really relaxing start, and it assured our service was good. Even as it filled up, the servers were attentive with bread and wine. But, as the food arrived, all courses, the experience significantly declined. 

Grilled Calamari: Sparse--4 pieces of Calamari served with greens and beans--subtle, odd texture even for calamari. Best part of that was the beans. 

Cod--Avoid. It's bland. It looked and tasted like it was flavored with a watered down red sauce and capers. 

Ravioli--mushroom, goat cheese, and something else. Sounded like a dream. Came served in a green, pesto cream sauce. And looked SO good.  And it was bland!! I was sad--this was the part I was most looking forward to. 

I cannot in good conscience recommend Bacco based on what I ate.
author: Chad G.

description: Fabulous meal, fabulous hospitality.  I went here on a business dinner and it was great.  We let the waiter choose our meal for us and we were not dissapointed.  We tried a little bit of everything and it was all wonderful.  I would go back with my family.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Yet another awesome spot in noe valley!

.. So I came in here early on some saturday evening for dinner. Customer service is excellent, food is on point and it's an overall very pleasant experience! A little expensive, but I would definitely come back again.


For starters, I ordered the meatballs and my date ordered pasta. I don't remember the exact names but both of them had that "melt in your mouth and melt your heart" sort of thing going on. Then, I got some ravioli (sooo good) and my friend had some steak (medium..it was perfect).. and finally to what I was dying to talk about.. THE DESSERT.. was just mind-blowing!!!! The apple-tarty ice cream pastry caramely thing was just orgasmic. I am still thinking about that thing. Wishing we did NOT share our desserts because I did NOT get enough!!


It does appear to be a little but more on the pricey side, so be prepared to spend at least $100.00 for two without drinks. I definitely won't become a regular here but this is a great treat!
author: Neek W.

description:
If you have a wheat or gluten allergy , no problem at this place. Gluten free cake , pasta and bread.  You can pick any pasta on the menu and it's gluten free .  Flourless chocolate cake was delicious. 
Thanks for bringing italian back !!!
author: alma h.

description:
Tonight I tried the fixed price menu for $37.00 per person.  It included a starter, main course and a dessert.
I had a hot  bowl of lentil soup to start things off .  The wind was blowing outside and the temperature was dropping--it was a perfect choice.
For my entree, I opted for the chicken scallopine which included a slice of eggplant on top and sat in a bed of mashed potatoes.  A very tasty red sauce was dripped on the first half of the eggplant slice.  Green beans and brussel sprouts were served on the side.  This was excellent.
Dessert was La Sfogliatina.  (puffed pastry with apple, vanilla gelato and caramel sauce.
I also had two glasses of a nice prosecco.
The hard, crusty bread and flavorful olive oil on the table were both plentiful and very good.
Bacco is charming on the inside and larger than it looks from the street.  I've been many times.   Each dinner has been very good.  It is located on a quiet part of Diamond Street--just around the corner from 24th.
author: Thomas D.

description: Fantastic food.  We were squished w/seating (table for 2) so it was uncomfortable and the wait staff seemed a little inattentive.  I'll go back and hope for a better experience.
author: Deb D.

description: Everyone at our table enjoyed the food immensely. We sat there for over two hours and did not feel rushed to vacate the table. The owner/chef came out to meet us . The wait staff were charming. At one point we sent back the kalamari because it was not prepared as we expected (our fault. We hadn't read carefully) and it was served with the salads. They gladly returned the kalamari to the kitchen. It was a little noisy, and one of our party had a hearing aid, so it was difficult for her, but that couldn't be helped. Altogether a lovely evening.
author: Susan A.

description:
What a nice place.  The decor is simple and pleasing as is the service.  The food is very good with large portions and reasonable prices.
Hubby and I went there early the other night and ordered the grilled, fresh sardines filled with mashed potatoes as an appetizer.  I ordered it because I had never had fresh sardines. They were quite good! Then for entrees he ordered their specialty, risotto which came with smoked salmon and pink peppercorns.  My husband makes the most incredible risotto, so this was a dicey proposition.  I ordered the appetizer portion of mezzluna: ravioli with ricotta and cod in a saffron butter sauce.  I really like that you can order any of the pasta dishes in an appetizer size. They were delicious! Fresh, fresh pasta dough and just enough of filling not the least bit "fishy" just a hint of the cod.
Now, back to the risotto: it came on a large plate and was a sizable portion for one person.  He ate ALL of it! They use the rice common to Venice rather than arborio rice, which is most common for risotto.  The grains are smaller and very creamy.
It was a great dining experience and we will return.
author: Mary D.

description:
I was so excited to learn that Bacco now had gluten-free pasta and bread!  Over the years I had eaten here several times and always had good experiences.  They were happy to work with me and find me something on the menu that was gluten-free, which usually turned out to be a steak.  So it was very exciting to finally get to try the pasta that my family and friends always raved about.  Our server was very helpful with my dietary restrictions and made sure everything was done right.

They brought out gluten-free bread with olive oil for dipping.  It was warm, moist, and tasty, and it was so nice not to be left out of the bread course.  I had the bacco salad with very fresh arugula and radicchio.  For my entree I chose the tagliolini with shrimp and arugula.  The GF pasta had a nice al dente texture and flavor.  We were too full to try dessert, but it looked like they had sorbets and gelato for GF eating.

Overall, it was a great meal and I am so happy that this neighborhood favorite has expanded their gluten-free offerings.  I will definitely be back.
author: L C.

description: Yummy, charming, fun, perfect stop for the family on a recent trip to SF.  Loved it.
author: Michele R.

description:
The Bacco salad was a delicious starter. The variety of pasta and complimentary sauces ran the gamut to satisfy every taste bud. I also got a side of string beans with spicy tomato sauce -- tasty way to enjoy green beans. Oh, and I can't write a review of Bacco without mentioning the exceptional green dipping sauce that came with the bread. Heavenly!

The staff are really nice, friendly, and respectful. I came for a birthday dinner (hence missing out on what sounds like a fabulous dessert menu because of birthday cake). The staff were super nice and accomodating when the group I was with showed up with a cake (hidden from the birthday boy) and bottles of champagne and wine.  

Our table in the atmospheric Bacco restaurant was crowded with champagne and wine glasses -- it made for a very warm, fun birthday dinner celebration. Thanks Ristorante Bacco for the lovely evening!

Note: I will probably up my 4-star review to a 5-star review next time I come back and actually get to sample your desserts! I am such a dessert person :)
author: Angie C.

description:
First time here. I had the rabbit pappardelle. They no longer have the lamb pappardelle which was previously recommended. Overall excellent, a bit salty. My friends had the penne with sausage and spaghetti with meatballs. We had the chanti "I sodi del paretaio" which went well with the rabbit and sausage. Service was adequate...perhaps a bit hurried at times although it was busy.

We came on a Wednesday night. Service was fast and attentive. We had a manager oversee our dinning expirence to make sure all was well. There is an option of getting gluten free bread for olive oil dipping.
author: Calvius W.

description:
Reading the other reviews here, I'm guessing we were there on an off night.  

I ordered the meatball appetizer which would have been very good if the sauce didn't taste like the chef dropped the entire container of salt in it.  My main course was the gnocchi with brown butter and sage and it was pretty flavorless, so much so I didn't finish it which is the first time that's ever happened with gnocchi in front if me.

But the worst part of the experience was the service.  We saw the busboy more than our waitress.  When our table was cleared, we waited over 10 minutes to get our check. 

Given the choices of other Italian restaurants in this neighborhood, it'll probably be a while before I try this place again.
author: Scott C.

description:
A very nice waiter helped us and made good recommendations.
Baby octopus was great
Most courses were very tasty. I was disappointed with some spoiled mussels that appeared in a seafood dish that was otherwise good. I was glad it came off the tab with no fuss, and happy with everything else. Will try again some time to see if I can bump up to 4 stars.
author: J C.

description:
My recent second trip to Ristorante Bacco confirmed my lackluster first impression: the food and service is mediocre at best. 

It was early on a Tuesday evening, and my party of six was one of the few occupied tables in the place. A group of boisterous businessmen entered, and I couldn't believe it when the host directed them to the table right next to us when the restaurant was nearly empty. Fortunately one of the gentlemen suggested it might be a good idea for them to be seated elsewhere. 

As for value, the restaurant is quite overpriced. We started with two orders of the meatball appetizer to share ($20 for six plum-sized meatballs). At that price, they had better be the best meatballs I've ever eaten. Unfortunately they weren't--while the meat was tender, the overly salty tomato sauce dominated the flavor of the beef. 

Next, the beet salad: sigh. The beets completely lacked flavor, as did the olive oil drizzled over the plate. A dash of vinegar might have countered the bitterness of the arugula leaves. The goat cheese was the only thing on the plate that I enjoyed. 

One person in my party ordered a steak, medium rare ($28). It arrived to the table medium well, with a charred, inedible hunk of radicchio and a tiny mound of mashed potatoes. 

The service also was a mystery, considering the lack of customers. We sat with our menus for quite a while before anyone came over to check on us. Once the entrees were delivered, our server vanished. My father-in-law, celebrating his 80th birthday, politely pointed out to a busser that he had inadvertently dropped his napkin on the ground. The napkin remained on the ground for the rest of our meal, and a replacement was not delivered. 

There are better places in Noe Valley to enjoy quality Italian food at a reasonable price.
author: Susan P.

description:
If you are gluten free- this place is a must! If you aren't gluten free, this place is still a must!!! Amazing house made pasta. Amazing warm and inviting ambiance. Feels like you are at an old friend's house, not a restaurant. Food is fantastic! 

We have come here twice- never disappointed. Great for group dinners. 

But here is why the place is my new absolute favorite place: 
Christmas dinner is around the corner, and my BF and his mom are both Celiac, so no Gluten, but traditional Italian big dinners call for Ravioli. For years, that has meant that my BF and his mom can't partake in the Ravioli course. But not this year!!! I emailed Bacco asking if there was any way that I could order 6 servings of Gluten Free Ravioli, and their wonderful and gracious Manger Luca replied YES! And a list of the different fillings they could do. I made my order, received an email letting me know when it was ready, I went and picked it up on Christmas Eve, and Ta-Da! No one was left out at Christmas! 

I am so grateful that Bacco could accommodate us! Special shout out to Luca Zanet for making the whole transaction so smooth and easy! 

Bacco is definitely a place I am proud to support and recommend.
author: Rosalind R.

description:
Vincenzo, Vincenzo, Vincenzo
Wish you could of taste the food tonight! The chef was off a bit.
Bacco is truely a neiborhood joint. Not ready for prime time.

Service was great and ambience is reasonable. Wine availability is adequate.
The beet salad was small, sprinkled with chopped lettuce?
But the pasta Lamb sauce was over Salted, portion small compare with  Divino. The Paste quality is second to none. Dessert was  off also. Pennecotta was too milky and Apple Tarte too under cook.
I would probably not come back again, the food prep quality needs to improve.

Ciao, till we meet again. may be back at Divino.
author: Bob W.

description: Loved this restaurant. Easy going, knowledgable and warm service. Good wine list and great food.
author: Norwich Lover V.

description:
Bacco is one of our perennial faves.  We can never understand why we're able to walk in without reservations nearly every time. It may be a cliche, but you really do feel like you're in a neighborhood restaurant in Italy: great European-style service, perfectly prepared food, and warm ambiance.

All of the waiters are Italian, and their European approach is evident: they're not just here while they write their screenplay or find their next tech job; they're professional waiters who know a lot about food (and wine) in general and Bacco's menu in particular. 

The decor is cozy and Tuscan-ish: large smooth terracotta tiles set on a diagonal covering the floor, color-washed walls, long/heavy curtains, and bas-relief sculptures of Bacchus and his nymphs. 

The menu changes seasonally, but many items remain year-round. Unless you've spent your life eating at Olive Garden, Bacco's not going to change the way you think about Italian food. But that's not really the issue: come here expecting good food, simply prepared. 

Appetizers cover a wide range: there's usually a soup (often bland and forgettable), a special salad (usually one of the best choices; they sound more boring than they turn out), and some seasonal small plate. In the pasta section, our favorites include a rigatoni dish with lamb ragu and tiny peas. The usual assortments of meat-centric entrees are workmanlike (and more expensive) and generally not quite as interesting as the pastas. But if you see something that catches your eye, go for it: all of them use top-notch ingredients and are prepared just as they should be. 

The wine list offers a good assortment of California reds and whites, as well as a nice assortment of Italian varietals. All are reasonably priced. We rarely order dessert, but on the few occasions we have saved sufficient room, we've been rewarded.
author: anita c.

description:
I had dinner at Bacco last night and it was AMAZING! 
I had the braised meatballs appetizer and they were so moist and delicious. For my main entree I had the gnocchi made with butternut squash and a gorgonzola cream sauce-- probably the best gnocchi I have ever had.
My date has a gluten allergy so we were thrilled that Bacco offers gluten-free substitutions for several of their pastas AND bread...
I was raving about the food to the sweet waitress and she gave us a COOKBOOK with recipes from the Chef for FREE!!!!! Amazing. I have never had such great service, she was a doll and I can't wait to go back.
author: Bren B.

description: We had a birthday dinner at Baccos last night for six friends, and it was terrific -- great food, lovely service, and a welcoming atmosphere.  The server did a really nice job of arranging a leisurely meal for us, which gave us lots of time to catch up and talk.  The food was delicious, wine choices were fine, and the mood just right.  Great destination neighborhood restaurant!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Bacco is just the place you want to find on a Friday night after a long week at work. Take someone you love and relax in for a great meal. This is a wonderful date spot, perfect for quiet conversation. 

The crostini with fava bean spread is not to be missed!
author: Miriam W.

description:
Fancy Northern Italian dining, very different from most Italian restaurants in the city, which are mostly Southern Italian restaurants. To note the biggest difference, the north uses more butter and creams whereas the south uses more tomato and olive oil.

This makes for a nice date spot. In fact, most of the tables are two-seaters. This isn't a place for the hungry man. Portions are smaller than your typical Pasta Pomodoro, but quality is definitely much higher. Their calamari (picture uploaded) was soft and slightly crisped with a bit of stuffing, served on a bed of cream. The pasta I had (picture uploaded) was a bit salty due to the meats, but it was well-prepared. The pollo (chicken, picture uploaded) was also a bit salty. (I'm beginning to think Italian meats are just salty!)

Anyway, I'm really more of a dessert person. I had thier torta di cioccolata (I hope I said that right, picture uploaded) - flourless chocolate cake served on a layer of crme anglaise. I could eat that all day.

This place is too rich for my blood, but it was a nice find. I'd recommend it to you if you're looking to take your date out to a nice restaurant in a young and quiet neighborhood.

JONASAPPOVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Very good food and quickly served. Waitstaff was very nice. It was also not crazy to get a reservation. They were even quite understanding when my 2 year old daughter played with the lights on our way out. This is a good place for a special night out.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I came here for dinner with a few friends when I was out in California a few weeks back. Bacco feels like it's in a more residential neighborhood, but it was plenty crowded when we came in for dinner around 8 PM. We got seated quickly, and although the restaurant felt a bit small, it was a nice, cozy, intimate setting to have a good conversation.

The food itself was very well-prepared Italian food. For appetizers, we got meatballs and calamari, both of which were delicious. The meatballs were a bit on the small size (and there were only 3 served), but the meat was well-flavored, and the tomato sauce didn't dominate the dish. The calamari was in a light cream sauce, and it was in some kind of pasta (not the typical deep-fried kind that I'm used to) - making it much more appealing than usual. The main course was the highlight - I had spaghetti with bolognese sauce. The meat sauce was well-flavored and complemented the wheat noodles quite well, even though I generally think wheat noodles have less flavor than cardboard. There was also some fresh cheese on top as well, which added a nice creamy hint to it as well. Dessert was the chocolate cookies with chocolate filling (they have a name, but it escapes me now) and glass of milk on the side. It was good, but I've had better desserts elsewhere.

Definitely a nice little Italian restaurant that I'd visit again, and the prices were pretty decent to boot. The bill got expensive become we got a couple bottles of Chianti, but it was a good time with good company.
author: Asuka N.

description: Had a totally SOLID dinner here tonight. Everything was tasty, especially my pork medallions. I also loved the syrah we ordered. The apple tart. Loved it all. Unobtrusive. but attentive service. Great bread with amazing olive oil dip. GO!
author: Andrew K.

description:
I used to live in Noe Valley and this was one of my favorite restaurant.
The food is consistantly good, their panna cotta is fantastic.
Good atmosphere, good service.
author: Yoko S.

description: Gluteen Free, yippeeee...  Food was great. Little off the beaten path small but cute. Will be back!
author: Kristen P.

description:
We had the pleasure of dining here this past weekend.  The atmosphere was fine, the food was excellent, but what stood out to us was the server. 

There was a small error with the order of the table next to us. The server realized the error prior to placing the meal on the table, served the others, and brought something for the patron to eat while the replacement was being made. This allowed the whole table to eat while their dinners were hot without making anyone uncomfortable. Not only that, the server accepted full responsibility and blamed no one. We found this whole scene unusual in today's world.  

We will return the next time we visit the city. We would also return based on the care the servers showed their patrons !
author: RED B.

description: They have been around forever.. solid Italian joint.. great veal dishes.
author: Mark S.

description:
Some of the best Italian food in SF.  All four members of our party thoroughly enjoyed every dish they ordered.  

Since I am currently not eating gluten, I was dreading going to an Italian restaurant.  I was shocked to discover that they carry gluten-free pasta that can be used with any of their sauces.  I had the gluten-free penne with alfredo sauce and added their rocky mountain chicken and porcini mushrooms.  It was beyond delicious.  They were very accommodating.  The buckwheat polenta appetizer was also gluten-free and totally amazing - very rich and perfectly flavored.  

My family was very pleased with the spaghetti and meatballs, the vegetarian ravioli, and the salads.  Though the prices aren't cheap, for a few bucks more then we would spend at Pasta Pomodoro, we got a meal that was a hundred times better.
author: Amber W.

description:
We were staying in Noe Valley while on vacation.
For our last night out, we decided to go a little up-scale.
Bacco was just the ticket.
We were early, so there was plenty of seating.  Even so, there was a large and loud group right where we had been seated.  The owner stopped by to say "hi" and even asked if we'd like to be moved to another area.  We declined and enjoyed the ambiance.
The food was well prepared and tasty, wait staff was very personable yet professional.
Everything was so good we may have overindulged a bit.
Next time we stay in Noe, we'll be sure to stop by Bacco again.
author: Mark B.

description:
I went here with my girlfriend yesterday evening, essentially on a whim.  Liked it very much.

What we ate:  Stuffed calamari, asparagus and proscuitto, fregola with mussels and clams, vermicelli spaghetti with meatballs, tiramisu

Pros:  Service!  Extremely warm and attentive.  Luca seated us, recommended wines, and took our order, all with a personal touch.  Couldn't have been better.  As for food, the calamari and the pasta.  Originally, we ordered the octopus antipasti but it wasn't available, and we were recommended the calamari instead.  Good thing we were, because it was phenomenal!  Three calamari "dumplings" essentially, stuffed with diced vegetables, accompanied by spinach and a delicious cream sauce.  Very tasty yet not heavy at all.  The pasta dishes were also very good, in particular the pasta itself which was cooked to perfection.  Oh, and the tiramisu was fantastic, without question.

Cons:  The asparagus, clams, and mussels weren't anything to write home about.  I like the meatballs -- they were light and on the dry side, almost like turkey -- but I could see how others would expect something a little more savory.  We were also disappointed about the octopus not being available, even though we were there at 6:30 pm for dinner.

On the balance, we had a great meal.  The service was excellent enough to be distinct, and the food was delicious to the point where I would want to go again just to try the other pastas.  Just as a point of personal preference, I would have liked a slightly more upscale setting, perhaps warmer lighting and better spacing of the tables and seats, while retaining the overall rustic-ness (rusticity?) of the restaurant.  Then again, prices were reasonable and therefore not inconsistent with the more casual decor.

4+ stars.  Go for the pasta!
author: Albert L.

description:
As a gluten-free person, I am THRILLED to tell all of you other Yelpers about their GF pasta option! it is FANTASTIC and they do a great job cooking it. A few things to know about Bacco:

- The first time we ate here, we were not impressed. My wife is vegetarian and ordered the butternut squash ravioli. They had actually messed up her order and she had to wait until everyone else was nearly finished eating, until she could even start. When it finally arrived and she was starving, her excitement was quickly squelched when she saw that they serve 2 ravs for a pretty high price. Needless to say, she left hungry and frustrated. 

- Months later we decided to try them again since we live very nearby. She had a pasta dish and really enjoyed it. Most exciting was when i learned that they had begun serving GF pasta AND they were very knowledgeable about what was/was not GF. 

- Last night we ate there. My wife ordered the gnocchi and, unfortunately, found it to be a little boring. It was tasty...just not that exciting. I had the risotto and it was fantastic! For dessert, we ordered the afforgatto and it came with a cookie in it. We regretted to have to send it back and request a new one due to the gluten. The dessert returned a moment later and it was hard to say to if they remade it or just pulled out the cookie. I'm EXTREMELY sensitive and did not get sick so that is a thumbs up! 

All in all, Bacco is on our list of places we will go back to. They have a nice, eclectic wine list that's not too overpriced, and foods for both of us. I'm giving 4 stars because it is good and maybe we will have an experience that will bump it to 5 in the future.
author: Min M.

description: Bacco has a new chef and that is very good news for he has elevated the cuisine to a much higher level. Nothing strange and trendy but for a wonderful Italian meal this place is highly recommended.
author: Robert H.

description: Been a few times. The first ranged good to decent. Recently went back and they were GREAT. Love the menu revisions- small interesting plates and large courses. All pretty authentic. Excellent service.
author: M M.

description:
The food is perfectly portioned where you are not overwhelmed by size. The Polpi appetizer is phenomenal! We had the squid ink tonarelli and ravioli for primi and the veal for secondi. All were good and flavourful.
Our server was awesome!
author: Hansel R.

description:
Bacco was a pretty much perfect experience from start to finish.  The restaurant is elegant and cozy, the staff is subtle but attentive and very welcoming, and the food is delicious.

I tried:
-Crostino (w/ cannelini bean spread, broccoli rabe and pecorino) and thought it was really unique because of the bean spread and rabe combo.  
-Pappardelle w/ tomato and lamb (very tender lamb, not too gamey, and very flavorful tomato sauce, and the pasta taste and texture were so fresh and spot on)
-Gnocchi (truffled cream sauce was good, I don't love gnocchi but the bf raved)
-Braised brussel sprouts (sans pancetta) and swiss chard - the sprouts were better than the chard, but I wish they'd grill or roast the sprouts instead of braising (i love crisp sprouts!)

I'd love to go back and try more (the steak dishes looked awesome).
author: Priscilla T.

description:
I love their vegetable pasta. It's a layers of flat pasta filled with cooked vegetables in the creamy sauce. Kind like lasagna. 
I like especially the pasta. It's not too soft or too dry. It's just perfect. 
If you like vegetables and pasta, I'd totally recommend it.
author: So Y.

description:
Went there on my birthday at the end of December with a gourp of five.  We made a reservation through OpenTable earlier in the week for 8:30pm.  When we arrived and gave our name, the hostess at first tried to seat us a table for two.  We reminded her that we were a group of five and she quickly  and graciously found and cleared a larger table.  The waiter was attentive and helpful and the food was good.  

Our biggest complaint was with the ambience of the restaurant.  By 9pm the hostess was seated across from us, apparently done for the night and eating her employee meal.  Right next to her was the manager/owner(?) parked at another table with a cup of coffee, his laptop and a pile of paperwork.  Soon afterwards, they started putting chairs on all the tables that were no longer occuppied.  By 9:30, when we received our entrees we all felt that we were intruding on the staff and should hurry and leave so they could close the place.  With all the employee activity, it was difficult to relax and enjoy our food and wine.Then, when we were finishing our food, the check appeared before the waiter asked if we would like anymore wine, desert or coffee.  Having worked in restaurants myself, I understand the desire to close up as quickly as possible so the staff can enjoy their evening too, but when it takes away from the experience for the customer, then the employees need to be patient and less conspicous when it comes to closing the restaurant.  And if they want to close at 9:30, don't take reservations for 8:30.
author: Tom D.

description: Bacco is easily the best Italian restaurant in the United States. I have eaten Italian food in various parts of Italy and the US, and Bacco is better than 99% of the places out there. Every time I visit San Francisco, this is a must-visit.
author: Lily P.

description: I went to the restaurant with a friend a week ago for their Dine About Town event. Ordered the Bacco salad for the first course, steak for the second, and sorbet for dessert.  The salad was delicious and the steak was amazing with the balsamic reduction sauce. However, the raspberry sorbet was too sweet and I could hardly taste raspberry flavor in it. Service was fine, but with half of the tables empty when my friend and I went there, I felt they could do a better job. Still highly recommend their food :)!
author: Sara Z.

description:
Bacco is a nice, cozy, neighborhood restaurant.  Be sure you make reservations.  Walking in will probably mean a very long wait if they can fit you in at all.
The pastas are wonderful and I love the daily risottos - be prepared to wait for it as it is cooked to order and really does take 25 to 30 minutes.  The lamb chops with reduced grapes are lick your plate clean good!  The flavors are simple but everything is fresh and well done.  
The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars is the wine list.  I really want wines by the glass and a nice variety of them to choose from.
author: Karen C.

description: This is our go-to neighborhood restaurant--my kids love it, and we go here for casual occasions as well as special ones (birthdays, graduations).  Over the years, the food has improved and most recently, the menu has become more adventurous.  We all love the vermicilli with small meatballs, but any of the pasta dishes are excellent.  In fact, we so love the pasta, that we've rarely tried any of the more traditional entrees.  Entree portions look generous, and the desserts are absolutely delicious (tiramisu or affogatto).  The service is warm, friendly, and the ambiance more upscale than a typical neighborhood restaurant. Highly recommend!
author: Christine H.

description: Very Italian (server) except for the Asian owner who was very plugged into the Italian experience having served this community for years. Food was good. I had octopus, which was adventuresome. My Rigatoni was too al dente for my taste and the sauce was not inspiring since I was told it was their signature pasta, which should have been more memorable. We went with a couple who were regulars and born and bred Italians. The owner treated us to s complimentary Muscato which was delightful. So there are more reasons to go to Ristorante Bacco than the food: friends and wonderful atmosphere and service.
author: Paul W.

description:
After being their neighboring business for close to 15 years, we, the owners of Pasta Gina realize that after eating there many times and never having anything, but, excellent food and service that this is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco. 

  The feeling of genuine caring, and attention to detail has consistently 
made for a wonderful eating experience. 

  Also, the fact that we are in the Italian food business and Gina (Joni) 
is a chef whose parents were both born in Italy, (Venice and Benevento) makes eating at Italian restaurants a highly critical and sometimes difficult experience. Bacco ALWAYS comes through. 

  We are proud to be their customers, as well as their neighbors in business. 

  We noticed that one reviewer had the perception that we, Pasta Gina, make Bacco's pasta. Nothing could be further from the truth, Bacco makes all their own pastas and they are delicious. Take it from people who know. 

  Also, even though I collect wine, we usually buy a bottle of from Bacco's wine list, because of the wide selection of wines that I don't often see, especially their Sardinian wines. 

  Lovely ambiance, excellent food and service makes Bacco a gem.
author: Gene G.

description: We had a great time here.  Location is a little off the beaten path, but that was part of the allure.  Food was excellent, service adequate, and atmosphere very fun. I have already recommended to others!
author: Brent S.

description: Bacco is like your favorite sweater: cozy, warm, familiar. After walking by it so many times, we finally tried it last night, and it has firmly cemented its place as my go-to spot for some comfort food in the neighborhood. The service was great, and the food was absolutely delicious. My hubs and I split two appetizers (the grilled baby octopus being the standout - the texture was just right and the sauce was to die for), and each got the smaller portion of pasta, along with a shared order of brussel sprouts with pancetta. It was the perfect amount of fantastic Italian fare, and at a reasonable price, to boot.
author: Rachel G.

description: Over the years have had a few dinners at Bacco. Neighborhoody, not a giant formula restaurant ( hmmmm Incanto comes to mind ) just great Italian food and great service. They make their pasta ! Have had many of their pasta dishes,  lamb, various fish dishes, clams and so forth. Always happy with the food, and service.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Lovely meal with my hubby and friend.  We started off with sharing the polenta and calamari apps.  The polenta was perfect for anyone who loves something hot, gooey, and cheesy.  This hit the spot for all three of us.  The calamari was also delicious.  So tender, and perfect with the radicchio.  

For entrees, both hubby and I ordered the Maiale - pan seared pork tenderloin with mashed potatoes, and a fabulous gorgonzola sauce.  I thought it was wonderful.  Husband was OK with it.  Our friend ordered the Tonnarelli - thin noodles with prawns and tomatoes.  She was also just OK with it.  Ah well.

Portions are not big, but with an appetizer, our dinners were more than enough. 

We had other plans for dessert, but the menu had two of my hard to find favorites - panna cotta and afagato!!!  Next time.
author: Denise M.

description: I've been here twice now and the food, service and atmosphere is absolutely great. From the food perspective, my wife and I have had a variety of their pastas, all of which were great, and an absolutely fabulous pork chop. The burrata is also quite good. The best item on the menu though is the apple puff pastry desert. I can honestly say without hyperbole that I think it's be best desert I've ever had. We will definitely be coming back!
author: David L.

description:
This is an honest review from neighbors that have lived in Noe Valley for 15+ years.

We went to Bacco before it was Bacco. We witnessed the transition, We know the owner and the manager.

We love this place. We love the food. We love the people.  This place is wonderful. The food is fresh. The wine is great. The prices are reasonable.

We always bring our friends and relatives here.  

Well, we always write a review on Open-Table and new we have written on on Yelp.

We expect this review to be posted and to stick and be available for people to read for at least 5 years from February 02, 2012.
author: rick l.

description: Bacco is a restaurant that I frequent with friends and family. One of the better Italian restaurants that I know of. I would not hesitate to recommend Bacco to anyone to is looking for a great dinner spot to entertain guests.
author: Steven M.

description:
When I want honest Italian food; just really well prepared, comforting and tasty pastas and meats, this is where I send myself. 

If you like crowds, the newest trendy ingredient  ridiculous combinations, or some Chronicle reviewer's rave's about cutting edge cuisine, don't bother coming here. You will be disappointed by their lack of pretense and unnecessary innovation.  

It's just delicious, reasonably priced food, with really good service in a tasteful dining room. Kind of like eating in Italy.
author: Statin Island V.

description:
Our party of 4 walked in on a Friday night (around 6p) without reservations and were seated immediately.  Service was amazing, as it's been each time we've come: water glasses refilled, wobbly table fixed without asking, etc.  Since we dine with a small child, we usually ask for the side area left of the entrance/main dining room.

The 'amazing' part - right after ordering, the bread/pesto arrived. And soon after (within about 10 minutes max), all of our entrees!  Extra kudos for keeping a toddler entertained with quickly arriving food plates.

Everyone ordered pasta dishes and "seemed" to enjoy them. I use the word "seemed" because it's cold/flu season and 1/2 of our party had dulled senses, so I can't accurately comment about their tastebud experiences. I had the tagliolini with rock shrimp/arugula and loved it - perfectly cooked pasta and very light, which was what I wanted.  Paired with a Sangiovese - delicious!

The kid (who has a good palate and is usually a good gauge of the food) sampled all of our dishes and enjoyed the rigatoni the most, followed by the tagliolini and the vermicelli/tuscan meatballs.

By the time we left, all tables (except one) were filled in our area.  The main dining area looked pretty full too.

Minor critiques: Pesto served with bread could use a little more flavoring; check took a while to get once it was busy.

Overall:  great service, homey food, cozy environment, kid-friendly. Be sure to ask the hostess (owner?) about the pear and tomato paintings...
author: M G.

description: Kind of shocked this place gets such good reviews. Is it horrendous? Not exactly. But at best it's mediocre food being proffered as authentic Italian. I had the squid ink pasta, but you couldn't even taste the squid ink under the red sauce. I also ordered a side of Brussel sprouts for $9 and got about five sprouts boiled or steamed and cut in half with butter on them...gross. Another in our group got the rabbit sugo that was mediocre at best, and the polenta appetizer was not good. I feel like the people who really like this place must just not be that into good food. My suggestion is to go to Lupa down the street - much better food and much less pretentious.
author: Meredith M.

description:
I was looking to eat something plain tonight and that's exactly what I got.

We started with the asparagus, prosciutto and cheese.  It was tasty but the prosciutto was a bit too chewy, to the point where I had to just swallow it whole.  The we got the special tomato soup which was really good.  It had bread cooked in it so it added some texture.  

For my entree I got the home-cooked thin noodles with arugula and rock shrimp.  It was okay. The noodles and the shrimp were a bit too undercooked and there wasn't really a sauce on it, it was really light.  I liked it, it didn't blow my mind, but it was definitely satisfying.

Our waitresses weren't too friendly and not too attentive.  For example, my iced tea would be empty for awhile before it got refilled.  But, one of our waiters made an effort and was really nice.  The restaurant is really nice except for the curtains you have to walk through, through the main doors.  It's kind of awkward.  There's also ample street parking (which is a BIG plus!!)

I would return because it was good, not great, but maybe I just need to try something else!
author: Marisa R.

description: Ate here on a short visit to Noe Valley, San Francisco. Amazing food, service, ambience.
author: Kt S.

description:
I've been wanting to check this place out for a while now, and tried to many times, but somebody would not want to eat here, due to parking. So, it's either I go alone, or with somebody that's car-less! 

It looks very nice inside, with the arches, and nice tile. Just watch those steps. I had the PERFECT table, and one I hope to get again. It was at the window, just past the arch down the two steps. 

I started with the Mistacanza (SP?) salad, with a Dijon vinaigrette. It was nice and refreshing and light. I might want to try the Bacco salad next time, as it sounds a bit bolder with Gorgonzola, maybe? Can't remember. But THAT is the salad I will get next. 

I had to try the Bucatini, which is one of my favorite dishes. It has Pancetta, tomato, onion, and chili. It was very good, and seemed small in the big bowl, but it was very satisfying. 

I could not pass up dessert and had the Apple in puff pastry, and it was also very good. 

Service was great, food was very good. I look forward to going back!
author: Michael M.

description: Went here with five friends for NYE this past year and had an excellent meal.  Great wine selection, excellent food, and even when it got really busy (it was NYE after all) we weren't rushed out at all.  They make their own pasta every day, so make sure you have some!
author: Mark S.

description:
The food, decor and service was average. Really cramped seating.
Not bad - but not exciting.
author: Hari B.

description:
What a wonderful place! The service, romantic atmosphere, and food is simply divine! 

We had the Rigatoni, Gnocchi, and lamb chops. All beautifully and perfectly prepared! 

The Tortino DI Cioccolata is AMAZING! :) 

It is expensive, but worth it!
author: Tiffany L.

description: They were overwhelmed with a large party the night we were there, so the staff wasn't as attentive as I would have liked, but they were friendly.  The food was presented nicely and tasted good.  I didn't really like the booth we sat in (we were in the area to the left of the entrance as you walk in).  If you make a reservation, request a table in the main dining area to the right of the entrance as you walk in, rather in the dining area with low ceilings.
author: L A.

description:
Delicious! Was here last night with a friend and this is a great little intimate date night spot to eat at (if you don't have go pay since it is pretty pricey)! Sunday - Thursday they offer a three course pre-fix meal with a number of choices for the entree. I had the gnocchi that was in a pesto and rock shrimp sauce. The crostini appetizer was alright but nothing to make me consider ordering it again, but the tiramisu - YUM! very light and not overwhelming.

If you eat before 7 on a Sunday it might seem like nobody eats there but the staff is very attentive regardless, something that other fancy restaurants sometimes forget about when it's slow.
author: Liz S.

description: Went here with my dad while he was in town this past week. I really enjoyed the beet gnocchi and the eggplant appetizer! Cute setting, the waiter was very knowledgeable about wine and food pairings (which we are not, so it was very helpful). It was nothing extraordinary but I was satisfied. It's a little out of the way for me to make it a habit to come here, but I'll definitely revisit when I can!
author: Anne S.

description:
The food is just O.K.  
The stuffed free-range chicken was really dry, which I would not have expected. The spagetti and meatballs was pretty good.
Very kid-friendly, very loud and great for a group. Not so great if you like to hear what you're dinner date is trying to say. 
Probably will not go back.
author: Linda V.

description:
Accommodating and good service. I am vegetarian and there are only two options on their menu. My third time at Bacco, I decide to ask if they have anything else. They told they could make any pasta dish I wanted. Perfect, I ordered long noodles with veggies and spicy red sauce. It was satisfying. 

My partner is gluten-free and would probably give Bacco five stars as it is the only restaurant we know of that carries gluten free pasta. I gave it four because I would like a little more variety. I have this same problem at most restaurants, limited options. They have always been very sweet and the service has never been disappointing.
author: max k.

description: Yummy GF pasta and double yummy chocolate flourless cake!
author: Samantha M.

description: Excellent service! My sister and I were in the mood for Italian food and decided to try Bacco. However, we failed to look at their times. Thankfully we were only 15 minutes early and the owner came out and invited us to come in! Just that one gesture was enough to make our experience enjoyable. Needless to say, the food was delicious! We ordered a veggie pasta dish...it was literally a pillow of pasta, stuffed with veggies and topped with sauce and cheese. Their sauce was very fresh and full of flavor. I liked the decor and the relaxing ambiance of this place. The staff were just as nice as the owner. We will return again!
author: Mina D.

description:
Let me start out by saying how pissed I am!

I am pissed that we just spent $200 (in this bad economy!) on a TERRIBLE excuse for a Valentines' Day dinner.

Our waiter was (what's another word for terrible...?) AWFUL (especially based on the price for dinner).  If we were seated at a generic, VERY inexpensive restaurant ~ fine,  I would have no real complaints.  But for a "fine-dining" restaurant?  No way!

We were seated by the host who dropped two menus on the table and walked away.  The waiter came up 5 or so minutes later and, without greeting us or telling us his name, asked for our order.  I asked if he could tell me a little about the menu (which I am GUESSING is a 3-course prix-fixe based on the printing of the menu).  His only words: "Everything is good."  Really?!  $100 a head and you have NOTHING to offer me??

I said I would need a few minutes (to discern what I could on my own about their menu items).  The host came over a few minutes later, and to his credit, had a very nice recommendation on wine and a few interesting things to say about how the Scottish Salmon is farmed and the delicacy of the ravioli (which I ordered).

The appetizers arrived a bit later.  Entirely forgettable.  Not so bad as to give me cause to send it back, but REALLY nothing to talk about.  I heard the table next to us say the same thing after they finished theirs.  And TINY!  (Writing this review, after a "three" course meal, I'm still hungry).  I had the Carpaccio with Taleggio cheese and speck.  (**Please see my note later about the Taleggio).  First of all, there was hardly anything on the plate.  One thinly sliced piece of ham (speck) with a tiny bit of warm cheese and some very thinly sliced pieces of pear that definitely looked like they'd seen better days.  And it was warm.  Carpaccio, in my book, is not supposed to be warm.  Maybe it's a style thing.  Whatever.  My fiance ordered the Skate broth soup.  WAY underseasoned.  Watery blahness.

So here's my note about the Taleggio:  When we walked into the restaurant, it really had the overwhelming smell of....... what is it....?...?...  Ass.  That's what it is.  Something smelled like it had gone wrong in the kitchen.  Very wrong.  But no.  I'm pretty sure it was the Taleggio on my appetizer.  (When the table next to us ~ on the other side of us than the table above ~ sat down, their comment was "Smelly Cheese, Table of 4"). 

Next comes the entrees.  They were actually pretty good.  I had the Ravioli and my fiance had the Lamb.  My ravioli was very good, but the portion size was VERY small.  Seemed more like the traditional pasta course at an Italian restaurant which is of course followed up by the meat course, because it is NOT ENOUGH FOOD ON IT'S OWN.  My fiance's lamb was good and was almost enough to be called an entree.

This is my favorite part.  The desserts were slammed on the table by the bus boy (who I do have to say was quite good at refilling waters and clearing our tiny plates of food once we had finished), who said nothing about it (just like the two courses prior to it) and walked away.  I had to wait 10 minutes to flag down the hostess (while our waiter came into the area three times never looking at our table) to tell her I wanted an after dinner drink to enjoy with my dessert.  That came a few minutes later.

Maybe I could forgive if the restaurant was busier and overwhelmed.  But no, they seemed properly staffed.

Maybe I could forgive if it wasn't so damned expensive.  I'm fairly certain the unit cost of our two meals was well under $10.

Maybe I could forgive if I wasn't still HUNGRY!  But no, my fiance is whipping me up an "after-dinner" course as I write this.

Maybe I could forgive if the whole place didn't smell like ass.  No helping that.

Maybe I could forgive if our terrible waiter at this "fine-dining" establishment wasn't wearing a freaking Bugs Bunny tie.  

SERIOUSLY?!?!?!
author: Liz B.

description:
Its in my neighborhood, so that's a plus.

The best things on the menu involve pasta and some sort of meat - it used to be lamb.

I had the crab risotto last time and it was ok.  I found the risotto to be overcooked vs al dente like I had in Italy.

The bread was a little subpar - it was a little hard, but not in a crunchy way.

Dessert was ok.  The Apple tart was ok.  The chocolate cake was ok.  Overall, a little overpriced for a meal.
author: M K.

description: Great Italian cooking in Noe Valley... everything here is homemade, right down to the noodles. They have a few vegetarian selections, but whatever you pick from the menu, I'm sure will be a winner. The establishment is a great place to bring friends and family, but if you're looking to be romantic, reserve a later reservation. They have a great selection of wines and the staff is pretty quick and very friendly. I had a pretty positive experience both service and food. I would go back here again! HAPPY EATING!!
author: Rob B.

description: A little disappointed they don't have gluten free bread anymore.  Took my daughter who just started a gluten free diet to Bacco's for her 24th birthday and was looking forward to offering her a nice italian gluten free dinner from start to finish.  We read so much about the GF restaurant prior to our reservation with rave reviews.  The menu was not as gluten free as we anticipated, to start there was no gluten free bread served to dip - apparently they no longer serve the GF bread.  Only 2 GF pasta choices and a few entrees/appetizers.  The flourless chococate GF cake was good as was the affogato, but nothing outstanding.
author: Cincia H.

description:
There are restaurants that you visit for new excitements and there are those restaurant that you visit for consistency in quality and for many happy memories.
Bacco has been such a restaurant to me.  In the most recent visit I had grilled calamari as an appetizer and steak with truffle sauce as the main course. Calamari was very fresh yet tender, coated in wonderful olive oil and herbs: a great execution for often underrated but a great ingredient.
