Medallion of beef was also excellent with well balanced truffle sauce. The menu is very thoughtfully designed with separate vegetable menu for those who didn't get enough of the excellent sides. I did not order pasta dish this time but from my past visits and guessing from the quality of other dishes, I assume the quality has not changed over 20 yrs I have been visiting this restaurant. For the residents of Noe Valley who appreciate things  European, I recommend you walk with your children ( and save your precious parking spot lol)  and visit this restaurant on Sundays. The chance is this place will take you and your family away to Europe for a little while.
author: J I.

description: We were seated at a cute little table by the front window nook.  The service was excellent.  Prices were a little high ($11 for a small salad, $22 for risotto).  Food was very good and promptly served.  Vanilla gelato with espresso shot poured over the top-- delicious way to finish the meal.  Overall experience was one of simple elegance...
author: Emmy S.

description: Had gluten free pasta and cheesy risotto with roast duck breast. Dishes were delicious!
author: Chris L.

description:
This is one of my favorite places; they always seem to be able to get us in and the menu is so solid. Definitely we are lucky to have it in the neighborhood. 
We've had big, raucous multi-bottle of wine dinners with bunches of friends and small romantic dinners with two. They never miss their mark. and we leave sated and happy.
author: johnny h.

description: Bacco is a great neighborhood restaurant.  The food is always solid and the staff extremely friendly.  I would recommend this to anyone looking for a quiet, decent Italian place for dinner.
author: Joe B.

description:
It's a fact: food tastes better after a 49ers' win.  The wins for the 49ers have been tough to come by lately, so this Sunday's win was particularly special.  I think it put me in a much better mood, which, in turn, boosted Bacco's rating.

My friend from Sacramento and I came here last night.  I thought that a quiet neighborhood restaurant would be empty on a Sunday night, but the place was actually busy!  I thought it was a good sign, and, as it turns out, I was right! 

We parked right across the street from the restaurant and took a second to take it all in.  Huge windows, perfect lighting and really high ceilings were all signs of a classy place.  Heavy burgundy curtains separated the dining room from the entryway - very East Coast!

The hostess, a tall Asian woman in an elegant dress showed us to our table.  We were seated at a quite table in the very back of the dining room.  As we walked to our table, my friend commented on how much that place reminded him of Italy, where he vacationed with his wife in September.

Our waiter seemed a bit aloof, and I could swear he had ADD.  He could not wait to move on to a different table, and he almost tried to rush us for some reason.  Maybe it had something to do with the fact that we were seated in the corner.  There were also plenty of so-called "regulars" at the restaurant, and I felt like they were getting all the attention.  

I opted for the 3-course prix fixe menu for $35.  After a cold day at Candlestick, I felt like having some soup.  The soup of the day was Cannellini beans and spatzle, so I went for it.  The soup was flavorful and delicious with just the right amount of spices.  

I went with the Bisteca (steak) as my main course.  My first choice was the gnocchi, but it wasn't on the prix fixe menu.  The waiter asked me if I wanted my steak rare, and I replied "why not?"  I normally prefer my steak medium-rare, but I knew he had a plan for me.  The steak was very tender and indeed prepared rare.  It was a small (6-8 oz) piece of beef, pre-cut into 5 thick strips of juicy organic beef,  The steak was served with roasted potatoes and a some spinach.  The steak sauce, which I figured to be a hybrid of A-1 steak sauce and balsamic vinegar reduction, was tart but zesty.

As my third course, I opted for tiramisu.  A generous serving of moist, sumptuous, rum soaked dessert was big enough to share (I didn't).

Overall, it's a wonderful, solid neighborhood restaurant boasting terrific ambiance and very good food.  I will definitely be back: I want to try their gnocchi.
author: Yan G.

description:
I made dinner reservations for Bacco for NYE 2012 and it wasnt a bad decision but i feel i could have done better. 

Bacco is a nice little spot nestled in between a very residential area in Noe Valley with a kind of dark entrance and location so be aware if your not totally sure what your looking for as you can miss it. Parking is on the street like most things SF so dropping off your dinner partners and parking a block or two away might be the norm for eating here. Upon entrance the dining room is dim lit but smells wonderful, with about 20-25 small tables and a small welcoming wait staff. Initially my service here was attentive with my first waitress who promptly took orders and was on point till she left. 
When the food came out i had ordered the pappardelle pasta with short ribs and it was infact quite taste. Very tender meat, well seasoned and the pasta and sauce was also well prepared. Im used to having very wide pappardelle pasta when ordering so when it came out only about 1/4" wide i was a little disappointed as i love noodles but the flavor made up for the lack of carbs which i was okay with. The rest of the food on the table seemed enjoyable to everybody with little to no complaints. 
The only issue i had with the evening was the lack of service after the food was delivered to the table. We hadnt seen our waitress in 15-20 minutes after finishing our dinner course and were trying to obtain a dessert menu to finish dinner off. After flaggind down (which i shouldnt have had to do) our new waitress she brought the menus and explained why there was a delay with no apologies and took the dessert order. Out of Cream Brulee on NYE knowing you are going to have a ton of tables and this early in the night (8:30) thats a no no. Went with the Tiramisu and have had much better in countless places and could have done without especially with the added wait and lack of service. 
Overall the dinner was great in terms of quality and taste, i would have loved to have maybe a little more on my plate 20-30% more to be satisfied but it wasnt a small portion by any means. Service could be improved upon especially on a night where you know you will have alot of tables and you only have one waitress from what i saw at a time. I wouldnt return the next time im in the city but i wouldnt say it was a horrible experience at all.
author: Jody S.

description:
Bacco is one of those spots that is great for a nice dinner for 2-4. The menu options are few, but the meal is memorable.

Service - 4 stars
Food - 4 stars
Atmosphere - 5 stars
Value - 3 stars
author: Greg B.

description:
There's no logical reason why we don't eat here more often. It's nearby. We buy pasta at the shop next door twice a week.  Friends and family from out of town always request repeat visits. I always feel like I need a special occasion to eat here because it's so good.

The food is elegant northern Italian fare, prepared perfectly and without pretense. You won't find smashed potatoes, infused anything, a gajillion confits or phony-cologne-y hipsters here. What you will find is a comfortable, quiet table perfect for conversation and sharing delicious dishes served by an efficient and unobtrusive staff. 

Out of consideration for my vegan friends, my usual bite-by-bite is edited. You omnis will know what I'm talking about. We had the $28 three-course, starting with a nice beet and (A) salad and a fantastic butternut squash soup that was spiced subtly enough to allow the gorgonzola (A) to compliment. The main courses were even better:

A: "I know I shouldn't, but it's been so long since I've had (B) Scaloppini. I'm really tempted."
K: "I know I'm having the Petrale (C)."
A: "As a kid I looooved (B). I know it has to be good here."
K: "Go for it."
A: "Yeah, you're getting the (C), and I just had (D) the other night. I know I don't want (D)."
K: "Just get it. We're gonna halfsie, anyway."
A: "You wanna halfsie?"
K: "Sure, if it'll get you to make up your mind. I'm hungry. The bread's delicious, but I don't want to fill up on it."
A: "Sweet! I get to halfsie the guilt."

As anticipated, the (B) was fantastic. The white wine sauce was well balanced and not overwhelmed by the capers. Cutie's (C) was even better. It was moist and flaky with a light seasoning and shaved almonds - absolutely perfect.

The desserts here are out of this world. I had a Torta al Arancia (orange cake) topped with whipped (E) and drizzled with both a tart orange sauce and sweet raspberry sauce. The strong fruitiness made it seem far healthier than it was.

A: "You have got to taste this cake. It's nearly as good as our wedding cake (true!)."
K: "Mmm, that is good."
A: "Good?! It's way better than good!"
K:  "Mm-hmm." (stuffing a piece of Puff Pastry Apple Tart in my mouth)
A: "OMFG. You win."

At this point, I discover that the special occasions were so because we ate here.
author: Andy R.

description:
I've wanted to try this place for years after hearing and reading all the good reviews, and I live in the neighborhood. A group of 5 of us went and at first they tried to cram us all into a table for 4, which would have been uncomfortable. They weren't super busy so we asked for an additional table and they provided one. Okay so far.

I had their house salad which was fine. My entree was the pappardelle, which again was fine but nothing as incredible as a lot of the reviews here say it is. The wine was good. I asked our server for a dessert recommendation and she suggested the peach/pear? tart. This was just disappointing. Seemed like it had been sitting around for a while, and I've seen better desserts in Whole Foods' bakery.

Service was a little below par, but yes they do keep your water glass full! So all 'n all not bad, just very okay. Pomodoro down the street would have been a better value with similar food.
author: Rob N.

description:
One of the best Italian food I had recently.  I loved that it is not oily like some Italian dishes can be. The atmosphere is modest but classy.  It's great for a first date (but I shouldn't be saying anything about dating...it's been over 10 years since I had one!)

And their prix fixe is a great value!  Four of us went here, and all of us were really happy with our food.  No misses.  All hits.  Gosh, I'd pick this place over Acquerello in a heart beat.
author: Mami T.

description:
A five star experience all around. Great service, warm atmosphere and flawlessly prepared Italian food. This is a great spot when you're feeling flush (it's pricey, so bring the plastic) and romantic. 

Don't skip dessert.
author: Mark G.

description:
Back when Gavin Newsom was still whoring his way through the city, I lived in Noe Valley.  In the year and a half that I lived in the land of strollers and labs, I went to Bacco only once.  Not sure why.  (Some things are not meant to be pondered, like how people are so stupid as to elect Ron Dellums and Chris Daly.)  Last week I returned for the first time in three years.  I am glad I came back.  

When we sat down we had to navigate our way around two groups of blue hairs.  One group was a couple on a date.  It was very weird.  Have you ever seen a couple in their seventies on a date?  It does not help the appetite.  I fought past the combination of amusement and pathos and buried my nose in the menu.

Our waiter had a vague resemblance to Hal Sparks...except he was Italian.  I think more restaurants should hire celebrity look a likes.  Gives me an excuse to not tip as much.  Hal...or whatever his name was brought us the requisite bread and olive oil.  Beware the bread and olive oil.  It can ruin your meal...in a good way.  I ate about half a loaf.  The oil olive was well flavored.  My girlfriend told me that it was rosemary.  I believed her.  (Why?  Because that's our job guys.)

We started with the burrata.  Very creamy and even more tasty.  It came with olives and arugula.  I hate arugula, but I loved it with the burrata.  Warning!  One order is more than enough for two people.  I had the gnocchi.  It was flavored with fontina cheese and black truffles.  Loved it.  The portion was perfect.  It filled me up without forcing me to pop the belt at the end of my meal.  That left enough room for the Panna Cotta.  It was good, but not great.  The entire dessert menu was less than inspiring, otherwise I would have given Bacco that coveted 5th star.

We did not want to drink a whole bottle of wine, so Hal suggested a specific glass for each of our meals.  This was a nice alternative to getting one bottle to match two very different meals.  Good job Hal.  I'll be sure to watch you when you appear on VH1's I Love the 00's.
author: Chris I.

description:
Thank you Bacco for being amazing! 

My husband and i live a block away, and i have passed this restaurant 2 times a day for 3 months.....finally we ate here (don't ask my why it took this long....) 

a casual and light Wednesday dinner....turned into an amazing meal that neither of us expected

Bacco's menu is filled with favorites from our time in Italy....
Baccala, Sardines, Braised Octopus, Wild Boar pasta
**all things i have not seen on a menu in SF yet, so we ordered all of them (Plus the meatballs which were equally amazing) 

the waitstaff were fantastic, chatting with us and telling us about the chef. seeing as we got 4 appy's and one main, the waiter has everything divided into a very sweet 3 course meal (sardines and baccala, followed by the tomato course of meatballs and octopus then our pasta) it was perfect. 

its nice to see a menu right out of venice.
author: Christine f.

description: My fiance and I came here for NYE dinner, we were greeted promptly. I came here because of the gluten-free pasta dishes they have. I had a delicious gluten free pasta dish with braised beef while my fiance had regular lasagna. They even had gluten free dinner bread! The atmosphere was warm and lovely! The staff and service was wonderful! Defiantly a must if you are or aren't gluten free!
author: Soraya S.

description:
Bacco is our 2nd home. We have been eating there for about 6 years (usually 1x every 2 weeks - no joke!) and we have come to know the staff and the food really well. Paolo is one of the most warm and genuine people in this city. Gianni is our absolute favorite! 

We go to Italy 2x a year and the daily risotto at Bacco is at the top in terms of authenticity, creativity, flavor and consistency. Best in this city for sure! The specials are always excellent, and from the standing items on the regular menu, the Rigatoni with sausage is addictive! The fresh fish of the day is always inspired and very fresh! The entire staff is very knowledgeable about the wine list which continually evolves. The crostini are excellent, and we always order the Insalata Bacco as our starter.

The restaurant itself is simple and reflective of the Southern Italian influences from Chef Vincenzo and Paolo (co-owners). The painting of ripe tomatoes was done by Paolo's mother. It is cozy and welcoming, and they make you feel at home. What more can you want?!!! I'm just thankful to live a few blocks away!

BUON APPETITO
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Nice place to visit in Noe. Good surroundings. Great staff. The food is not bad. 

We went there last night for a special dinner out and choose Bacco. Nice little place. Everyone was really nice. I ordered the red snapper and my wife had the osso bucco. The snapper was done in a simple if slightly bland tomato sauce. In tasting each other's plates, my wife and I noted our dishes had pretty much the same sauce. Not complaining, just found it surprising. 

We had a good time and enjoyed the wine. It was a bit on the pricey side, so be prepared to spend. We probably wouldn't elect to go back on our own, but if friends invited us to go, we absolutely would.
author: Bob R.

description:
THE PLACE
* this an awesome date place 
* romantic
* quiet
* awesome service. 

THE FOOD:
The tuna here was excellent.

CONCLUSION:
Nothing much else to say, this place was awesome.
author: Michael S.

description:
For the life of me, I cannot understand all the hoopla over this place. Perhaps I went on the worst night of the restaurant's life, but everything about this place was bad.  My dinner mate and I walked in and stood about for a good five minutes before anyone even approached us.  Though the place was almost empty, the waiter attempted to seat us next to another couple in a table arrangement befitting a cramped space -- the kind of seating where you're so close to the other people you may as well just shove the tables together.

My request to be moved to the empty side of the restaurant was met with a look of befuddlement.  

The menu was standard, nothing exciting or new.  I ordered the butternut squash ravioli, my boyfriend the pasta with bolognese sauce.  What we got were bowls of awful and even worse.  My dish was passable at best.  The ravioli was overcooked, the filling and sauce uninspired -- and the plate ungarnished.  I guess it was both a good and bad thing that there were only four or five sad, limp pieces.  Seriously?  

But at least I didn't get the bolognese sauce.  Limp pasta covered in what looked, smelled and tasted like what I imagine Hamburger Helper would taste like.  No joke.  We were both so furious we refused to finish the food on principle.  Still hungry, we went to another restaurant to eat normal food.  

Our experience there was so bad that neither one of us wanted to go to an Italian restaurant for the longest time.  We still refer to that night in disgust.

If you're in the neighborhood, skip this place.  Go to La Ciccia instead.  It's a few block south, smaller and intimate with better fare for the same price.  At least you won't get something out of a can there.
author: Helen C.

description:
I'll keep this short and simple. This restaurant is perfection. 


Perfectly cooked food. Perfect service. Perfectly charming ambience. 

Simply perfect.

My deepest condolences to the family and friends of the owner, Pablo.
author: Susie O.

description: We've been going to Bacco since it opened but tonight might have been the best meal ever (and there have been several).  We started with the butternut squash gnocchi with brown butter and sage sauce and it was to-die-for delicious (and I like that they split it for us in the kitchen).  For the main course, we had the duck with balsamic sauce over black rice.  It was solo amazing.  It is the rare restaurant that can get duck right (not overdone but not too rare).  And the black rice was the perfect compliment.  The duck was on the special menu so not sure how often it is available but felt very luck tonight (thank you Sherry).  Dessert was the flourless chocolate torte di Isabella (named after the owner's daughter) and it was awesome  - dense but somehow not too heavy.  The place has been rejuvenated by some new faces.  Gabriel, the manager, is knowledgable and personable and has a real passion for food and wine.  Our server, Davide, also was extremely knowledgable about food and especially wine and was perfectly attentive.  Sherry (the owner) does a nice job of checking in without being intrusive.  The place has a great vibe these days and we are so happy it continues to thrive as one of San Francisco's best neighborhood restaurants.  Salute Bacco!  P.S.  Try one of the new Super Tuscan wines.  We have no idea which one we had, but Gabriel or Davide will steer you in the right direction.
author: Maggie P.

description:
I had an excellent meal here with some friends last week.  I haven't found many Italian restaurants in the city that I really like, but I definitely enjoyed my dinner at Bacco (I also like Caffe Delucchi in North Beach and Delfina in the Mission, but those places can get pretty crowded, if you're even lucky enough to get in in the first place).  I ordered a pasta dish with all of my favorite ingredients - ahi tuna, olives, and *spicy* tomatoes.  I also sampled other people's dishes and thought that the food was consistently good. The eggless raspberry and mango panna cotta was amazing.  I am a chocoholic, but I enjoyed the panna cotta more than I did the flourless chocolate cake (which was also good but just not *as* good).

The waiter was friendly and patient.  He didn't seem to mind that we still hadn't decided on our orders the third time he came by our table.  Prices are on the higher end, but when I want cheap, simple Italian food, I just make it myself at home.
author: Grace W.

description: I was taken here for my birthday by one of my favorite friends and needless to say I enjoyed it immensely.  The food was superb and one of the better Italian meals I have had in SF.  I recommend coming here and sharing your plates family style.  The pasta is lovely and one of the few places in SF where you can order gluten free pasta.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This review is really 4.5 stars.

The food was excellent.  I had the vermicelli and the apple puff pastry.  I enjoyed the wine, even though most of the nicer selections were Italian wines (which I know little about).

The space was cozy and the wait staff was excellent.

The only reason Bacco loses a half a start is because we waited for 10 minutes upon arrival, even though I had a reservation.  And, the food came out of the kitchen extremely slowly.  To be fair, it was a busy night, and every table was full.

Lastly, the bread is wonderful!
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Two words sum up this place:  Bland.  Expensive.

I was disappointed by the spinach ravioli with pine nuts in a cream sauce that was described by our waiter as "vegetarian pasta" (there were only two dishes on the menu that were meatless), and came with no garnish whatsoever.  My girlfriend had the other vegetarian entree, gnocchi in red sauce, which was equally tasteless.  

The service was excellent, which is the only reason this restaurant gets two stars instead of one.  

I really wanted to like this restaurant since it's in our neighborhood and the ambiance seems so nice... but I honestly don't understand why anyone would rave about the food here.  It's just plain boring.
author: Sleuthy W.

description: I thought Bacco was only okay, which was somewhat disappointing.  One, it is in the middle of the residential area of Noe Valley (not much going on otherwise).  Two, service was mediocre at best.  We arrived on time with a large group and the table was not fully setup.  Then, throughout the night, the waitstaff was not particularly attentive.  Three, the food was only okay.  Note, the small portion is not that much smaller than the large portion.  Pro?  The restaurant itself has a romantic and dim lighting ambiance, but beyond that, unlikely I will be back.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Sad news!  We met him twice when we dined in Bacco and he was very nice and friendly. 

"(04-13) 21:22 PDT San Francisco -- The owner of a popular Noe Valley restaurant is missing in Hawaii, where he entered the ocean on a spear-fishing expedition and never returned."

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/04/13/BAKG17216G.DTL&feed=rss.bayarea
author: Ile F.

description:
Finally an Italian restaurant that doesn't begrudge you for ordering something without meat.

Whenever I come home to visit family, we always end up coming here. It's a nice quiet place with excellent food, even if the waitstaff is a little snooty.

They have some of the best olive oil for dipping bread into, but be careful if you ask what kind it is, they don't like divulging secrets. It's imported straight from Italy though, I haven't been able to find it anywhere in the city. Oh well.

I normally flip flop between the risotto and the veggie ravioli. Both are delicious. The Risotto changes every day, and doesn't always sound great, but when you do get it is cooked to perfection. They have a good wine selection if you buy by the bottle, but not that great by the glass.

Overall this is a really cute noe valley restaurant that I would definitely recommend.
author: Allyson S.

description:
Oh no.....they have fallen from grace.
I have eaten here 2 times since my May review, thought it needed an update.
The host and hostess (i think he's an owner) are rude. Not friendly, barely greeted us. The attitude is they are doing you a big favor by letting you in their restaurant. Maybe this is why on a recent Saturday night the place was only half full. Oh well!  Onto bigger and better restaurants.
Too bad I like  the food.

Bacco is the complete package!
Fantastic food, great service, and wonderful ambiance!
Definitely a place to check out. I can't wait to go back.
Wish i could give it more stars.
author: Jack G.

description:
I truly love dining at Bacco. The food AND the service remind me of restaurants back in Italy.  And good ones. 

A solid list of  tried and tested pasta, seafood and meat dishes is the backbone of a menu that always includes pleasantly surprising seasonal variations.

My favorites:

The Burrata with prosciutto antipasto is a classic to be tried. Loved the Buckwheat polenta with gorgonzola, fontina cheese and wild mushrooms to start the meal, especially when it's a chilly night outside. 

My pasta entrees personal favorites include pappardelle with tomato lamb sauce, spelt spaghetti bolognese and, above all, potato gnocchi with black truffle and Fontina cheese. 

Among meat dishes, I strongly recommend the stuffed veal with prosciutto, mozzarella and carmelized onions. It melts in your mouth. 

Then again, seasonal specials are always worth a try. Bottom line, great, hearty Italian cuisine.
author: Matteo F.

description: We love Bacco. Introduced by a friend, it has become one of our favorite go to restaurants in the City. The food is fresh and delicious, and the staff always treats us like we are their special guests. Davide is a wonderful waiter, very generous and thoughtful with us time and time again.  I highly recommend Bacco. It is a special, consistently delicious dining experience.
author: Shai M.

description:
My parents were visiting and felt like Italian food.  I was worried about parking, so we headed to Noe Valley and I yelped for a place.  Were we lucky.  I loved my beet and goat cheese salad and the gnocchi which you could taste was made fresh (as is all their pasta).  They liked the place so much (and the concept of yelp) that my mom wrote the following review:

The evening after we had enjoyed Postrio, we happened upon Ristorante Bacco, a last minute decision.   From the warm welcome to the final farewell, we were especially pleased by our experience.  While we had been conscious of the effort made at Postrio to provide a fine dining occasion, everything seemed effortless at Bacco:  friendly staff, helpful suggestions on wine and food, excellent selections, particularly the  delicious apple dessert.  An altogether pleasant surprise.
author: Sarah X.

description:
This has become a favorite spot for my wife and I.  We love the service.  We love the food.  We love the ambiance.  Each time we go it's been a great choice to the delight of guests and ourselves.

If you enjoy a nice Italian dinner, I would recommend this place hands down.  There is a great wine list and the specials are always good.  If they have the halibut available you are in for a treat.  The puff pastry is a fantastic finish for any meal, although a cup of coffee with the Tiramisu is a joy in and of itself.

When you go, make sure you allot time for the meal--appetizers, main course and desert usually take 2 hours.  Also, this was a great choice for a birthday party for a group of 10, they were quick and it was a hit for all those that attended.  This is a gem in Noe Valley.
author: Daniel S.

description:
At first, I wavered between 4 and 5 stars.  I was going to give it 4 stars, because the prices are high ($18 - $22 entree range), with smaller than average servings.  But then I remembered that after the appetizers, bread, and wine, I was too full to even finish my pasta.  The servings are perfect if you can let yourself forget the "bigger is better" attitude many of us Americans have, and actually listen to your stomach.  

The bread is pretty amazing -- they must bake it in house.  

The Pinot Noir (Pinot Nero, on their menu) was so good that I asked the waiter to write down the name of it for me.

The appetizers were tiny.  I ordered the calamari, and it came with 3 pieces, each about the size of my thumb, and stuffed with a vegetable / cheese filling.  Small servings, but delicious.  The other appetizer I tried was the terrina -- also small, but very flavorful.

I ordered the Tonarelli pasta (tomatoes, artichoke hearts, prawns).  The noodles tasted home made, different from any other Italian restaurant's noodles I've had.  Like the other items I'd tried so far, it was fresh and full of flavor.  The prawns were big, and cooked perfectly.

I really loved the atmosphere -- nice lighting, Spanish tiles, pretty arches framing each room.  It had a cozy, intimate feel, perfect for a date, or catching up with an old friend (who is paying for your dinner :D).

The service was really warm -- our waiter was really sweet, friendly, and attentive.  And he was actually Italian.  The hostess filled up the water glasses every fifteen minutes or so, and the owner or manager came by to make sure everything was good.

It was.
author: Jessica C.

description:
North Beach is known for the Italian food. I'm thinking cause its so close for the tourists.  Most of us here know that the REALLY good food is served outside this area.

I'm too lucky to live within a few blocks of this place and I don't even feel bad when the weight I lose, gets put right back on after eating here.  I really do love this place. Anything on the menu is perfect. The waiters are friendly.  I doubt I will ever get tired of eating here.
author: Marie ..

description:
Wow!  LOVED it!  

A great Italian restaurant in Noe Valley that has charm, authenticity, and originality.  From the vino, to the antipastas to the entrees...everything at this quaint cucina Italiana was wonderful!  This would be a great place to have a romantic evening with a special someone.  

The staff is actually from Italy and they were all so friendly and delightful.  Not to mention, gorgeous! :) ...but we're not reviewing the servers are we? haha! 

We started with the organic green salad that had a house dijon dressing along with the fresh bread and olive oil.  We pared our dinner with a bottle of the Donnaluna red.  For my main course I had the gnocci with black truffles in a fontina cheese sauce that was truly spectacular.  I couldn't help but take a gander at all the other lovely dishes that floated by on trays to other tables.  Everything looked amazing!  Definitely try Bacco! Run, don't walk!  Oh and the leftovers the next morning were just as good as when I actually ordered it! haha!
author: Candice M.

description:
perhaps the very best Italian restaurant in SF possessing none of the fanfare but all of the quiet confidence.
A cozy eatery hidden off of Noe Valley's most exciting drag.
The fava been crostini is worth eating slowly so you can savor every bit of flavor.
The waiters are thoughtful in their wine suggestions to complement your dish.
The pasta is well cooked and the sauce not too heavy.
Make this evening as special as it deserves, enjoy it with one or two people you truly love.
author: Sean S.

description:
Just came back from dinner with my husband & a friend at Bacco.  The best Italian food I've ever eaten.  We three had prix fix and ate off of each others' plates.  We had home cured salmon, cold cut  plate and beets salad for appetizer.  Oh yum yum yum.
Then we had Skit steak, Lingcod and Squid ink pasta.  OH YUM YUM YUM!!!!
Finally, panna cotta, flourless chocolate cake and Tiramisu for dessert.  OH YUMMY YUMMY YUMMMMMY!
The dinner was perfect, service was awesome!
Will definitely go back!
author: Spoon K.

description: This is a Solid Italian Restaurant in Noe Valley. It's a bit hidden since it's off Diamond. But I would come here again. My Rigatoni dish was really tasty and I would get it again. We had a few appetizers as well and I would simply recommend anything on their menu
author: Eric A.

description:
I am a sucker for good pasta.  In fact, I probably would choose pasta as my last meal if I were on death row.  It's a fact.  As with certain foods, pasta imo is one that is not hard to do.  How can someone mess up noodles, pasta sauce, and cheese?  Sadly I have been to establishments where this simple creation can taste like cardboard.  Never a good sign!  

I first tried Bacco with a good friend a few weeks back, who was in town visiting for the weekend.  We were both pleasantly surprised when we walked into the establishment as the mood and décor were absolutely beautiful.  VERY classy indeed.  We were seated immediately by an individual who seemed to be the owner.  Another classy touch.  After reviewing the menu (there were many delicious sounding choices) I settled on the Rigatoni, a delightful concoction of rigatoni pasta, tomato cream sauce, bell peppers, peas, and homemade Italian sausage.  Soon after arriving, the bowl was practically licked clean!  The pasta was so delicious, and all of its ingredients were so incredibly fresh, I was more than pleased with the meal.  

I liked it so much that the next time I visited Bacco, I didn't even look at the menu, knowing good and well that I wanted this particular dish again!  Mixed with excellent service, authentic and helpful staff (our waiter was very charming and Italian himself), and the freshest of fresh ingredients in every dish, Bacco is a restaurant that I will without a doubt frequent again in  what I hope is the not too distant future.
author: Ryan H.

description: Declicious, gluten free pasta options and great service.  Very accommodating. I would definitely return.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Came here for a first date last night.  I don't know if I would have chosen this place, but I don't think my date had actually been here before.  From the outside it is a very cute location.  A tree-lined mostly residential street with well-kept Victorians, the restaurant is nestled right between a church and corner market.  It is low and flat and looks very upscale so I was glad I had dressed up a bit and not gone for  a more urban look.
Inside its got a nice décor.  Small but with white table cloths, yada yada.  All so good so far, but the first sign that this is no Delfina is that the crowd seemed to be from an AARP meeting.  Not to be age-ist, but I was surprised some of the diners didn't drop their dentures into their wine glasses when they were done with their meals to soak for a bit. 
Okay, so it was more my nana's crowd than mine. 
When we turned to the menu, it too seemed a little old-fashioned to me.  But I went with it.  My date was funny and I was happy to be on a date after a bit of a dry spell this summer. 
We started with the calamari, which was nicely prepared. Not chewy.  It was okay.
He had the vermicelli with little tiny meatballs, which after some Alec Baldwin on Saturday Night Live jokes, he let me have a taste of.  Good little meatballs.  Not heavenly but good. 
I had the cod ravioli, which was pretty good.  Well-prepared but a bit under-seasoned for my taste.  
We briefly considered staying for the chocolate ganashe cookies with milk but I think he sensed I was underwhelmed by his choice of dinner spot and we decided to just move on to first date part two.
Overall, I would say this is a good place to go with your parents, maybe, but I would not recommend it for first date spots if you are under 50.
author: Nikki K.

description:
My VVSP and I had been wanting to try Bacco for a long time, based on friends' raves.  Last night we finally gave it a try.  Lovely from start to finish.

We brought our own wine, so I didn't get a look at the wine list.  If it's as good as the food-which I suspect it is-it's superb.  The service was perfect--attentive, but not too much so.  Honest answers with no fawning.  Beautifully prepared food in a lovely dining room.

We shared a salad of baby arugula, radicchio, walnuts, and gorgonzola, and a pasta dish of penne with smoked salmon in a pink sauce.  We each ordered the pork with mashed potatoes and spinach.  We agreed that the pig must have led a very happy life to be so delicious.  We split a side of grilled asparagus dressed with pecorino and truffle honey.  For dessert he had the buttermilk panna cotta and I had the apple tart in puff pastry with vanilla gelato. 

Oh, my--what a superb meal from start to finish.  The waitstaff was there when we needed them and otherwise left us alone--real pros.  

We will be back, without a doubt.  Thank you, Bacco.
author: Earline A.

description:
The reason I chose Bacco was because it was so well recommended on the "Check Please Bay Area" program the other day. I even ordered the rigatoni. It looked very inviting, an intimate and quiet setting in Noe Valley. And indeed it was, the service also being very accommodating and efficient.

But the food was altogether just solid, and not spectacular as I would have hoped. The rigatoni was actually excellent --served hot and the sauce was pleasantly flavorful and spicy. The pasta tasted wonderfully fresh and the peas, peppers and sausage were fantastic. I could taste even a hint of fennel.

But the salad --the simple greens with the balsamic dressing --was way too strong. Not the greens. Not the freshness. The dressing was both salty and strong in its flavor. It could have even used some lemon to take the edge off.

The biggest disappointment was the tiramisu, which no self respecting Italian restaurant should ruin. Didn't taste fresh. It was too cold. It didn't taste enough of the espresso and it felt like a Pepperidge Farms cake creation. Clearly I have had much better. My companion's puff pastry with apples was nice and I was able to have a bite. By the way, her daily zuppe of potato/leeks was great, although she probably shouldn't have had pepper put on it.

We had the $35 prix fixe meal which was pretty cool ---1 appetizer, 1 entree, 1 dessert but some of the choices are limited. That's fine. And altogether it was pleasant but there are much better neighborhood Italian spots in the City. Want to avoid the crowds in North Beach? Then try Bacco.

Finally the coffee was just so so ---it was not strong at all, it also wasn't especially hot either. The cappucino was just OK.
author: Alfonso L.

description: The food is only ok but the ambience is nice - it's a large and open restaurant and it wasn't too hard to get a reservation or to find parking!
author: Cathy L.

description: Delicious! Went on a Friday night for a late (9ish) dinner. The place was almost empty, but the food was great. He had the pistachio crusted pork chop and I had the lamb papperdelle. Both were terrific. I could have done with a few more veggies with the pork chop, but it was cooked perfectly and perfectly seasoned. We definitely were shutting down and we only saw our waitress to order, but we understand that SF is sort of an early-dining town and people want to go home. Would definitely return for an earlier dinner!
author: christine c.

description: Awesome place for people with Gluten and/or Dairy allergies! The staff was so knowledgable and friendly.  So happy to find this gem of a restaurant, I will definitely be back!
author: Lindsey T.

description:
What a great restaurant for gluten free and non gluten free diners. I spent the weekend in the City and wanted to do Italian. As a person with celiac disease I need to make sure the restaurant has wheat free entrees. After a thoroughly disappointing meal at Pucinni & Pinetti Friday night I had a gem of a meal at Ristorante Bacco. The manager there has been gluten free for four years and understands what gluten free means. The waitress was wonderful and could explain exactly what was in every item and which ones I could eat, which ones they could modify, and which ones I couldn't eat. 
The restaurant is in Noe Valley, but easy to get to, particularly if you happen to be out in Golden Gate Park. It has nice decor with cloth tablecloths. The wine menu is diverse Italian wines.
I had the whipped salt cod with polenta as an antipasti. It was great. For the main course I had a lot of different gluten free pastas and sauces to choose from, but I decided on that night's special of shrimp and risotto in saffron. That was just phenomenal. The cherry on the cake? They make their own gluten free bread. Gluten free diners know what this means because we can usually just stare at the bread bowl.
The non gluten free diners in my party thought their meal was as good as it gets. They raved about the stuffed calamari ( was told I couldn't have because vegetable stuffing was made with wheat) and the meatballs. They had different pastas with seafood and meat sauce respectively and the sauces were to die for.
The bottom line here was my guests thought the meal was as good as they have had hands down. From a gluten free perspective where you expect you have to give a little when you can't have wheat (particularly at an Italian restaurant), there was no compromise. The manager told me it is not uncommon for a gluten free diner to give him a hug after the meal in gratitude for the meal. I don't know why everyone doesn't give him a hug. The meal was fantastic.
author: J H.

description:
I came here to celebrate my birthday after seeing this place on "Check Please" and I'm so glad I did. Now, I should preface this by saying that I was surrounded by great friends and good wine, which automatically makes any experience enjoyable. That said, I think that even without the good company the food would still have been good. 

I'm a big risotto fan and after hearing about their risottos, I assumed that that's what I would order. But I couldn't resist the sound of the black truffle gnocchi with fontina sauce, which was amazing. All of my friends' pastas looked good, too. One rebel ordered a meat dish, which was also very good. And another person ordered a fish dish, which came with swordfish and another kind of fish that I can't remember. That was also very good. 

They loose a star for the dessert, which didn't quite live up to my expectations. I have the philosophy that if you're not having dessert, there's no point in even eating, so it's an important part of the meal. The apple tart was actually pretty disappointing. It was too much pastry and too little apple or caramel. Perhaps I should have went with the chocolate.... 

The service was adequate, I thought. They only had one bottle left of the wine we ordered, so when we wanted a second bottle, the waiter gave us a great recommendation in the same price range. 

Overall, I'm glad we went but with all of the possibilities in the city, I doubt I'll be back. Besides, if I kept going back to the same places, I would never eat my way through San Francisco in my lifetime!
author: Amy B.

description: Just moved to SF from Boston and found Bacco while apartment hunting.  Great vibe and great food.  Gnocchi are soft and pillowy.  The BEST.  Service is as good as the food.
author: Michael C.

description:
For these price points, go to A16 or Quince.

While convenient for me, there is no compelling reason to return to Bacco.  Lackluster.  

For you, there are many other stronger substitutes city-wide.  

It's not "bad" food, just bland and uninspiring.
author: babsie g.

description: My favorite Italian food in San Francisco.  The Sacchetto is TO DIE FOR!!
author: Sarah B.

description:
My sister had heard great things about this restaurant so we decided to give it a try.

Neighborhood was cute and the restaurant atmosphere was cozy.  Service was excellent.   We started off with two antipasti - the Bacco salad and the Polenta - which were tasty.   I selected the Rigatoni, my sister ordered the Tagliatelle special and our aunt chose the Fregola.  

The Rigatoni was good, but not divine like other yelpers have mentioned.  The Tagliatelle with Dungeness crab was tasty.  And the Fregola was presented really well and a little spicier than expected.  The portion sizes are perfect (you won't overeat) - just like the other yelper mentioned, just don't get caught up with "Bigger is better" and you won't worry too much about the price of the entrees.

I wasn't too excited about their wine list and the two wines our server recommended (from the by the glass section) were just ok.

I did save room for dessert as I really wanted to try the Apple Tart.  I was NOT disappointed.  My sister chose the Tiramisu which was just ok.  

I good dining experience, but I wonder if I came on an off-day?  I'd like to give 3.5 stars, but since half stars aren't possible, I decided to round down.  I couldn't quite justify four stars.
author: J L.

description:
Fabulous. My uncle loves Italian (grew up in the east village when it was still Italian) so we took him here when he visited. He's a critic, yet he left happy. I can't remember a particular dish--but I can tell you that no one left unhappy. Not to mention, bring a bottle of Barolo and you're set. Oh wine and pasta.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description: Comfortable on a cool drizzly sf night, and not too noisy. Enjoyed a wonderful meal with friends which is unusual for me... Living with Celiac disease, it is very rare to find a restaurant that truly understands what 'Gluten Free' means.
author: Janie F.

description:
Amazing, delicious, fresh, flavorful Italian food, including wonderful gluten free pasta and bread.  Yum!

The atmosphere is nice but unpretentious, and the staff warm and welcoming.

But the best part is the delicious food, and what a treat to be given fresh gluten free bread to dip in the flavorful olive oil (as well as the house-made gluten free gnochi).
author: Lisa P.

description:
Personally I feel that Italian food is the most overrated of cuisines.  Not that I dislike it; it's just that, like the Greek classics, it gets a lot of uncritical praise from our euro-centric society while other, equally deserving regions get overlooked.

Nevertheless, I'm always interested in a new elegant restaurant for taking out-of-town guests, and Bacco fits the bill perfectly, especially if said guests have a more...conservative palate.  Great location on 24th St, and nice warm lighting, too polished to be homey but still feels unique.  Food, as Italian goes, was quite good (I especially liked the single giant ravioli).
author: Wes M.

description:
I had been channel surfing a couple of weeks ago and low and behold, on one of the restaurant reviews, they talked about Bacco.  Everyone was fairly crazy for it, so I got very excited about trying the place!  My family and I went here last night for dinner and although a nice experience, I don't know if I would rave about it.  

The ambiance as you drive up is great; there are two large Eucalyptus tress in front lit up for the season (I think.  And sadly, the two trees are potentially going to be replaced by new trees.).  The restaurant seating area is nice and it wasn't too loud.  We got the Polenta and Bacco salad to start.  Isn't polenta supposed to be creamy and not gritty?  In any case, it had good flavoring.  Then came our entrees.  My Aunt got the fregola which she inhaled - luckily, we got a taste in before it was gone, and I think my sister and I thought it was nicely spicy and tasty.  I got the crab tagliolini special which was quite lovely.  My sister got the rigatoni which was served perfectly al dente and had a nice sauce.

For dessert, we shared a Tiramisu and the Apple Tart.  Definitely get the apple tart - very tasty!  The Tiramisu was ok, but just didn't compare to the apple tart.

Overall, a good experience (although my sister obviously hated the glass of wine they had suggested and they didn't take note or offer to exchange it with something else).  Not sure I'll be running to come back here, but definitely could see myself giving it another try!
author: A L.

description: A fantastic menu, which includes fresh, made-in-house gluten free pastas & breads! This is GREAT for the gluten free diners!  The wine list is decent & the staff members are super friendly. Owner/manager is very nice & handsome, to boot! I highly recommend Ristorante Bacco!
author: Jody A.

description: Great restaurant!  Bacco is definitely a hidden gem unless you live in Noe as it isn't on any major streets but it is a great find.  The service was good and the owner/manager was there to greet us, check on how the meal was and send us on our way.  The food was delicious.  I would recommend the veal as the main course.  The apple tart dessert was great too.  Would definitely visit again.
author: Blake B.

description: Pretty good calamari and nice pasta with seafood and pancetta.
author: Jim J.

description:
My family and I went here for my birthday this year which happened to be on a Monday. I was wary of trying this place because I don't tend to trust Italian food in the City; it tends to be overpriced and bland. Also, we had my 3 year old niece with us and you know how City people love to hate on little kids.

Woo hoo! This place fought off both those stereotypes. The food was delicious, fresh, and piping hot. I ordered off the prix fix menu (Mon - Thurs, very affordable) which included a soup, an appetizer (more like a mini entree) of gnocci (awesome, not gummy at all), and short ribs (which were incredibly tender and flavorful). My dinner mates were also satisfied with their pasta dish and salmon, respectively. 

And I got free dessert to boot! Awesome.

The one star off was also for the service, more like 0.5 star. They were actually very nice and accomodating to child but a bit slow with coming to check on us. I can't imagine what it would be like on a busy night.
author: Salina Z.

description:
Where to begin? This is a charming restaurant, that may have the best italian food I have had since Italy, (besides my Italian side of the families cooking).
The Scene:
Tucked away in Noe Valley, this rustic yellow walled, arched restaurant gives the feeling of an Italian villa. It has the small intimate feel that every first date begs for, the aura of a family gathering that makes it feel like home, and the dreamy staff to help you fantasize about an Italian getaway, (yes, the waiters are all Italian with accents). 
****NOTE**** This restaurant is not good for late night dining, by 930 the place is empty. Come here at 6 and enjoy an entire evening.

The Food:
Get the risotto! It changes daily, and is AMAZING! However, beginning with the bread, it is fresh, warm and delicious, served with olive oil. 

Burrata-imported from Italy, this cheese is to die for...a MUST get
Polenta-anytime polenta,cheese and honey are combined...try it

Tonnarelli-this fresh made pasta with prawns, pancetta and porcinis....delicious! ...and I;m picky about my red sauces
Gnocchi-I love gnocchi and truffles, however this dish seemed a little mild for me. For someone who has never tried truffles, this would be the perfect introduction
Risotto-changes daily...AMAZING....get it

Panna Cotta dr Mango e Lamponi-I love plain panna cotta, throw in mango and rasberry and this dessert is worth the trip alone....I would come here and get this to go
Tiramisu-This dessert is a classic, and as any true Italian knows, marscarpone is the only way to make it. This is heavy on the espresso, and melts in the mouth
Sfogliatina Di Mele Con Gelato-Apple puff pastry with vanilla gelato had me licking the plate. I almost skipped it because apple tart didn't sound amazing....let"s just say, you WILL regret it if you don't try this dessert

$35 Three course Prix Fix Menu Sun-Thurs....although the prices are reasonable, so you aren't stuck with the prix fix 

Parking may be a pain, and yes, it is a little far, but it is worth it! I love this place and will come back frequently, simply to taste every new risotto creation they come up with.
author: Bianca L.

description: GREAT GLUTEN FREE FOOD!!!  Wow, almost everything is or can be made gluten free.  They totally understand the allergy.  They even have gluten free bread.  On top of everything the food tastes great.  An extra bonus is the service is good too.  I highly recommend this place for both gluten free and non gluten free people.
author: Daune F.

description:
In the sea of moderately priced, medicore eateries that have huddled themselves in Noe Valley, this is a totally delicious, cozy, and (dare I say- inexpensive!) place to curl up for a great din din-- it's a great date spot, especially if you're not sure she's going to put out.... (I kid, I kid.)

So!  The skinny:

-- Homemade pasta (I assume from Pasta Gina next door?)
-- Great wine list
-- SUPER wonderful service.  The waitstaff bends over backwards to make you happy, AND they are very knowledgable about the menu... our guy made great recommendations in addition to making us smile.

One of the other things that I dig is that it's pretty quiet inside-- perfect for conversation, but maybe not  too well-suited for getting hammered and making loud fart jokes.  Just a warning.

Next time you're out for dinner in Noe and don't feel like waiting at Firefly, give this a shot instead. Humor me.
author: Laura F.

description:
Ristorante Bacco feels like a restaurant where you could have a 3+ hour meal like they do in Italy and feel right at home doing it.  I'm not saying they encourage that, but you never feel rushed or pressured to leave.  I love the wait staff here - the Italian waiters are so nice, funny, and charming.  

The food is excellent.  Good solid homey Italian food.  Their pastas are wonderful, solid wine list.  

This is a great place to bring a date, or your visiting family, or anyone, really.
author: Miu M.

description:
Wonderful Italian homemade pasta for the palette.  The burrata was delicious as a starter.  I also had an amazing red wine (don't recall the Italian name), but it had a full-body flavor and was so smooth.  The Puff Pastry Apple Tart w/Vanilla Gelato & Caramel Sauce dessert and coffee were also incredible.

One plus is that they have a great prix fixe menu Monday - Thursday for a great price.

The restaurant was beautifully decorated, very welcoming and the service was excellent.  The place is quite charming, along with the waiters.
author: Lisa C.

description:
We live close to Bacco and finally checked it out last Friday after walking by a million times. We were quite impressed. 

The service was outstanding. The food was excellent, I highly recommend the lamb pasta dish if you like lamb and the panna cotta was great too. We enjoyed the wine, meal, service and ambiance. 

There was more than enough food, I had to take home the rest of my pasta dish and had a delicious lunch of it the next day. They also have a great deal for prix fix if you go Sunday - Thursday.
author: Abby W.

description:
My parents come into town about once every month and we always try to go somewhere different and special. Last time they were here we went to Karamanduka in the Richmond. This time I wanted to try somewhere in Noe Valley and since we all love Italian I mad reservations for Friday night. 

We got to the restaurant a few minutes late (damn parking), but it wasn't a problem, our table was waiting for us. Service did seem a little slow yet was good. The deal is as "Kathy W."  points out is that the food is bland. Yes, you can tell it is fresh but where are the flavors. Of the four main plates that were ordered I would really only consider ordering one of them again- the rigatoni.

I don't think I will be going back to Ristorante Bacco. If this place was in Nebraska it would be something to talk about, but in SF, it just doesn't cut it.
author: Lee M.

description:
My Italian friend told me about Bacco years ago.  She said their food is authentic, and I should give it a try.  I'm glad I did!

They had squid ink spaghetti in their special menu for a while (now it's gone unfortunately), and it was so good that I've had called them and specially ordered for my reservation if it wasn't in the menu that day.  

Their bread is great (heard that they bake their own), and my fav dessert there is puff pastry apple tart w/vanilla gelato & caramel sauce.  Thinking about their food makes my mouth water.

Their prix fix menu is available for $38 from Sunday through Thursday.  Some items (like big steak) may cost extra like $4, but it's a good deal.  I often go there with friends, and one or two of us get prix fix menu and share dessert and appetizer.  And we usually end up being way full than we wanted to.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I accidentally stumbled into this place (firefly was packed!) with a friend of mine...I had no idea what to expect, but the waiter was super friendly and speedy, the atmosphere was comfortable --- not too casual, not too fancy..just right.

The wines left a little to be desired...but I had already had 3 expensive glasses of red wine before arriving at the restaurant...so my palette was a little ruined from that.

The food was excellent, I ordered the Pappardelle ---it was amazing, the fettuccine was fresh,it had little pieces of lamb chunks which woke my taste buds up, and were so tender...I'm salivating just thinking about it again, and the lamb sauce pulled the whole dish together.
author: Zubin I.

description:
I really wish I loved Bacco, because I adore Italian food and I live so close to the place.  But after eating there three times, I have concluded that it is just okay.  The ambience is nice.  The food is pretty good.  Most recently, I had the gnocchi, and it was a bit bland but still decent.

As for service, our waiter was kind of a turd.  He seemed bored out of his skull and way too cool for school when taking our order.  When he asked us if we had any questions about the menu, he really meant, "I hope you don't have any questions about the menu, because if you do, I will be bored to tears and will answer your questions on perfunctorily." Which is exactly what happened.

Bacco is also overpriced.  It costs as much as Firefly, but you don't get the exquisite food or the superlative service.  It's not a bad option if you can't get a reservation anywhere else, but it shouldn't be your first choice.
author: Ariel S.

description:
Went here during the Dining Out For Life as hey, it's a good cause and this place makes their own pasta.  The entry way is a little small and gets quickly cramped when people are standing around waiting for a table. The place was packed for a Thursday  night, which was probably because of the DOFL going on.

I recently had surgery so was there with a wheelchair and a reservation (which we were a little early for).  There were a few tables empty, which they didn't seat us at and instead said that it'd be a few minutes.  Other people came in and got seated before us (which ALWAYS makes me angry!  Minus 1 star for that!).  I don't know if it was because of my wheelchair or what, but it made me feel rather uncomfortable as my boyfriend and I sat there waiting so long for a table when we had a reservation.  My boyfriend has a bad back and there was nowhere for him to sit and he was in a lot of pain having to stand for that long.

We were finally taken to our table, which apparently the owners decided that it'd be better for us to have a 4 person table as I was in a wheelchair. Really, a table for 2 would have been just fine although it would have been nice to have been asked as otherwise we'd have eaten and left by the time they finally sat us down (that's how long we were waiting).

The food is excellent though and our waiter was very nice.  I had the pappardelle, my boyfriend had the rigatoni, and we split a side of the brussel sprouts.  We also both had a glass of primitivo.  The bread is really good too!  I would come back just for the bread, but the pastas and brussel sprouts left me wanting to come back as it was just that good.

Luckily though the owners redeemed themselves in the end of making us wait forever and a day for our table as they comped the wine!  It was very nice and professional for them to automatically do that without us having to verbally complain to them about the wait so at least they were paying attention!  I gave them the benefit of the doubt since it was busy, but definitely give them props for not having to be told that we were waiting a ridiculously long time for our table.
author: Kelley P.

description:
solid.  came here when contigo, firefly, la ciccia, incanto were all full (had no reservations)
hurray for iphone opentable and yelp -- got an 8:30 slot here 5 min before...
northern italian wine selection
chose the pinot nero with the rigantoni (homemade sausage) which was very tasty
the parpadelle with porchetta was lighter and also good
shouldn't be hyped up (i.e. michelin recommended, etc.)
and you'll have a decent Italian meal with a pleasant ambiance and note the adjacent next to an Italian market
author: Rob C.

description: Bacco is one of our favorite Italian restaurants in the city. Have been dining there since they first opened about 10 years ago. Have watched their beautiful daughter grow into a beautiful young woman. Have tried just about everything on the menu and the food is consistently well prepared and tasty. Their fresh bread is amazing. I love pasta so the risotto and the rigatoni are among my favorites. The dishes are generous. For the first time ever last night, I was able to eat my entire rigatoni dinner it was so good. I usually take some home for lunch. My partner is a meat eater and enjoys the vitella veal and also the ravioli. We always start with the little gem salad. We never eat desserts, but tried the meyer lemon curd with butter crust. Toes were curling in joy shortly thereafter. The Italian waiters are well trained and attentive. Even the support servers like Rafael are friendly and make you feel at home. And the decore and atmosphere will help transport you back to Italy. Buon Appetito!
author: Nick P.

description: I don't write many reviews but felt compelled to do so for Bacco because I had such a good experience.  The dishes were authentic, and the staff/owner create a familial feel throughout the entire restaurant.  They clearly new many of the patrons and took time to have a dialogue with customers.  Service was great, and the food was fantastic.  I look forward to going back.  Another great Noe Valley restaurant.
author: Rob A.

description:
The reason we came to Bacco was that friends of ours lived in the area and they love the place. We also happened to see the restaurant featured on Check Please Bay area. We went on a Monday night, and called ahead for reservation. Hostess was wonderful , we were seated promptly and were actually surprised the place was packed. 

The restaurant has a wonderful atmosphere, low level lighting and "cozy". even with the paver tile floors the place was not that noisy. 
The service here is just outstanding. The hostess, bus boy, and waiter could not have been better. 

The food on the other hand is just OK. We both ordered the Bacco Salad which was good. Toasted walnuts with arugula, radicchio and blue cheese with balsamic dressing was very good. The main courses we ordered were the Veal, and the Pasta with shrimp and porcini mushrooms. The Veal was on the bland side. the pasta looked and tasted more like a chow mein..way too salty and I think the porcini was on vacation that night as it never made an appearance on the plate. 

The wine selection is interesting. All Italian wines, but hey it's an Italian restaurant, but no wines under $36 (1 bottle at that price) and the rest ranging from $40 to $175? (I don't think so!). We ordered a dry white wine at the suggestion of the waiter and it was actually a good choice with the meal but still pricey... 

Desserts are all priced at $8. We ordered a tiramisu and the puff pastry apple tart with the house ice cream. The tiramisu was just OK, but the Apple Tart (Oh my god), it was wonderful... 

Overall the food is just so so except for that apple tart. 
Prices are way to high for what you are getting. 
The restaurant needs to revamp their wine list and make it more affordable.. 

All together it was pleasant but there are much better neighborhood Italian spots in the City at half the price...
author: Jim R.

description:
I have to agree with Alice C about the Gnocchi - some of the best I've ever had.    

Although the staff seems a little put out from time to time, the chef has a real sense of craft here.  From the Chicken Pamasean to the the house marinara sauce, the flavors are delicate while not straying far from tradition.  

Thumbs UP: the Gnocchi is great 
Thumbs DOWN:  Staff not as accomodating as they should be.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I'd really like to be able to rate this higher but overall it was just an average experience for me.

Starting with the good, the space is nice and lively but not noisy and doesn't have the feeling of being crowded even when full.  The service was very good (though I do wonder whether our waiter's italian accent was real or not).  The menu reads well and features a broad range of selections and prices with a nice list of daily specials..  I really enjoyed my veal piccata entree and the veal special my mom ordered was good as well though.  But that's where things start to switch to the bad.

As an appetizer I ordered the special Crostino which featured eggplant and an olive tapenade with onions.  I think there might have been one piece of eggplant skin on there but mostly it was just an oily mess of onions and capers.  For dessert I had the chocolate cake which was entirely average.  Both the appetizer and entree were about 2/3 the size they should have been.

In terms of price, for what I ate it was expensive.  To start, I think the menu on the web site is old and everything was a buck or two more expensive.  I did like the fixed price option of an app, entree, and dessert for $35.  But after adjusting for the veal choice it was $37 which is too much for a bad appetizer and average dessert.

I won't rule out a return to Bacco but I'm not exactly sure what circumstances would lead to it.  It's too expensive to be just an average evening neighborhood dinner but not nice enough to warrant any special occasion.
author: Jay W.

description:
Solid Food.  I grew up in an Italian household and this reminded me of those special Sunday meals.  

The home made pastas were wonderful, and the veal, very unique.  

What held this back from a full star review was that some of the food temperatures of my party were off, some dishes simply were too cold, and the service.  It isn't a good sign when you have to take thee bill up to be paid as you are leaving.
author: Ken p.

description: I just had the worse meal of my life at Bacco. The food was tasteless to horribly bad. The waitstaff was competent, however. I can not recommend Restaurant Bacco to anyone who is looking for good food in a pleasant surrounding. I will never return to the restaurant.
author: Tom G.

description: So, I decided to go to dinner with my lady and we chose Bacco because it looked nice from the outside and we were in the mood for Italian food.  Everything was going fine, the servers were polite and helpful.  They told me that they had a pinot noir special, so we ordered two glasses of this wine and it tasted corked -- not work $12 a glass!!!  we then ordered the Crostone as a appetizer -- unfortunately I could slap I a piece of Columbus salami and mozzarella on some bread and it would have tasted better than this.  I thought for a minute this must be a joke.  Then I ordered the most expensive plate on the menu, the flank steak ($28).  When my entree arrived, I was mesmerized. It looked like a big taco, but when I bit into it, I realized we should have gone to a taco truck instead of this place.  The food was bland and lacked seasoning.  the salad was like out of a salad bag from trader joes. As I stared at my meal, and stared at my lady, and realized this could possibly be our worst meal ever, I had to laugh out loud -- literally LOL!!  When they came how the meal was, I had a hard time responding without laughing in their faces -- I just told them that everything was fine, but I would not recommend this place to friends, but would to somebody I didn't like.  The food was way overpriced and tasteless.
author: Jamal B.

description:
Went to Bacco with friends and got there fairly early on a Saturday night and there was no wait!....You enter through a Wizard of Oz-esque curtain and come into a charming, small atmosphere with several people ready to get your own little personal party started..
We were particularly impressed with our server's help with gluten-free recommendations from appetizers to desserts.
The beet salad appetizer was the best of the salads we ordered. The rigatoni with gluten-free pasta was outstanding, as was the sacchetti, and my friend loved, loved, loved her spicy baby octopus appetizer. The only so-so dish among the three of us was the mushroom risotto, which was just a  little bit overcooked and salty (one of the specials that night)/ The house Chianti was very good.
Overall, a very nice evening with delicious food, friendly, intelligent service, and an upscale but relaxing neighborhood atmosphere.
author: Victoria M.

description: Bacco is charming! Our group of 6 was seated comfortably by a window and spent a great evening eating and drinking. The service was super helpful and accommodating ... as the token gluten-free member of the party I appreciated our waitress' help to navigate the above-average GF pasta/sauce combinations. Loved that they had gluten free bread for me to snack on, too! I was disappointed that there was no GF ravioli this time around, but thoroughly enjoyed my butternut squash gnocchi. A glass of moscato for dessert rounded it out perfectly. Yum!
author: Anna R.

description:
I want to give 4 stars to one of my favorite cozy Italian restaurant in town. Nice homey Italian decor, authentic Italian waiters, at least one Italian cook. Burrata is the best one in San Fran. in fact is imported every few days from Italy. My favorite dish is the Angus steak in balsamic vinegar reduction and all the handmade pasta, gnocchi included. Risotto is spectacular if cooked by the Italian chef. Don't miss the dessert wine Recioto, much better than any Port wine on the earth. Recioto wine has a lot of history, check it out and than sip it while enjoying their chocolate flour less cake. Desserts are all magnificent. Ciao e buon appetito ! Paolo the owner and all Italian staff rock !!

my thoughts and prayers go to Paolo's family
author: Biemme B.

description:
Very solid Italian in a nice space, however I felt a bit close to my neighbors...  They could pull a table or two to make a bit more room.

The fare is upscale, more gourmet then not.  Pasta Pomodoro this is not.   

The service is impeccable and they have a pretty solid wine list.

I dig this joint, but like other reviewers, for some reason I am not there as often as I would like.
author: Tony A.

description:
Thanks to previous Yelp reviews I booked this restaurant for a Mother's Day dinner, and everyone was impressed.  The atmosphere was very comfortable and casual but still maintained its elegance.  It's not so casual that you can show up in your jeans and flip-flops, but this is definitely not a pretentious crowd.  The service staff was excellent as they came by several times throughout the evening to make sure that we have everything we need.  The food was soooooo delicious that I ate half just so I can save the other half and eat it again the next day.  I got the special pork chop.  My husband got the veal w/artichoke and that was excellent as well.  

The average tab per person with glass of alcohol is probably high $20's to low $30's.

Overall everyone loved their dinner and even my brother-in-law complimented that this was a great choice for dinner.   

I would definitely come back again.
author: Star Y.

description:
recently had dinner at bacco and was pleasantly surprised. walked in with a group of 6 after firefly was fully booked. luckily bacco was open and had the space to accommodate and the food was good!

had a great time and the place was full by the time we left! :)
author: Art A.

description:
It's New Years Eve; where should we go? Don't want to spend $$$ to get drunk wearing pointy hats. 

How about something quiet in the neighborhood? I called Bacco. They could take us early; i.e. 7:30 because of a cancellation. Perfect.

We arrived on the dot, and only had to wait a few minutes. It was full, yetI could hear myself talk! 

The service was smooth, timely and professional. The food was very good. People say it's bland. I say I can taste the ingredients- it's got beans, I taste beans, it's got tomato, I taste tomato. And when the ingredients are fresh and first-rate, that's all I want to taste.

No, the portions are not huge, they are right-sized. You can actually have room for dessert  without feeling like you need a Goodyear sign on your stomach when you leave.

It's a perfect place to come with a friend or two and have an adult meal.
author: Keith W.

description: The fava bean risotto was the best I've had. Delicious steak with balsamic reduction. The apple tart is a must have! $35 prix fix is a great deal. Highly recommend for some great Italian cuisine.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Expensive for what you get I think- I think i am already being liberal with the stars.  The service also was not the best- while the waiters were attentive up to the ordering- my water glass was often empty and while we may lingered after paying as it was a get together and were the last ones in the restaurant- the waiters had already left and the bus boys were sitting waiting for us to leave near the door.  Very odd feeling...didn't feel especially like a friendly neighborhood place.

The bread and olive oil tasted really good to me as i was pretty starving upon arrival- which was a good start- possibly my best part of the meal.  Split the calamari appetizer that was good, but not great or especially flavorful.  My pasta which the waiter recommended-parpardelle with tomato lamb sauce- was average- as in is this really homemade and not overcooked because i can get better pasta at pasta gina next door and make it at home better than this- and i'm no chef. ( I also have grown up eating homemade pasta dishes)  I am going to write it off though, since my dinnermates both liked their dishes. My wine was a chianti- better than the other two wines being drank at my table- which doesn't make me feel good about the wine by the glass selection.  The tiramisu was so so- i can be a little picky since this was my favorite dessert as a child and have tried hundreds of versions.

The tables are very close together and they have paper tablecloths on top of the regular tablecloths- which seems to contradict the ambiance- which is otherwise quite cozy, slightly upscale and date-like.  The waiters did seem like they spoke italian and had thick accents (from somewhere). But even with that- i will not likely be back for a while with all the other restaurants i like or want to try in the area.
author: Maria F.

description: Bacco is a friendly neighborhood type of place. The manager greets you immediately. The chef makes his own pasta and bread and has gluten free options. The food is good. Some of it was a bit mild in flavor ( baccala, specifically) but I finished my plate it was still quite tasty. They have a good italian menu not just boring lasagna but diverse and fun items to pick from. Everything is very fresha nd the service is outstanding. Oh yes, good wine selection too.
author: Jannelly D.

description: Service was attentive and the food was good and well presented. Had the affogato for dessert. The vanilla gelato could use some more oomph, though. But overall, a pleasant dining experience.
author: April B.

description: The best pasta!  Cooked to perfection.  I got the lamb ragu and the meat was tender and yummy.  The hubby got the mussel and clams and it was the best we've had in a log time.
author: Gina T.

description:
It kills me to give this place one star. I was so looking forward to trying Bacco. Zagat had given it good ratings which raised my expectations. 

It's hard to mess up beets, which were prettily plated.

I want to pay compliments, as our waiter, upon hearing we plan to go to Italy, took the time to advise us on locations we should visit. They also brought us more ciabatta when we asked, and they removed the other bread (dry and tasteless) from the basket. 

We ordered crostini that were not fully toasted with mushrooms that had unappetizing flavor. That decent beet salad raised our hopes, which were promptly dashed by a King Crab risotto that tasted like pure mac and cheese. Kraft cheese, not even a good parmigiano-reggiano. The crab was notably absent. 

I'm used to a seafood risotto that has, well, chunks of seafood in it. I'm also used to risotto having a creaminess and a bite, not the texture of overcooked instant rice. We put down our forks after one or two bites. The kitchen noticed. We should have explained the issue, but they had been kind, and I didn't want to offend. However, serious restauranteurs probably do want to know, so next time I'll find a nice tone to tell them their food is terrible.

Service can't make up for bad texture and flavor.
author: Simone E.

description:
Pretty authentic Northern Italian fare.  No complaints about the food, other than my most recent Osso Bucco was over done.

We had efficient service and it was well-paced.  Crowd is very Noe Valley...

Only real quibble is the tables are very tightly packed - not a place for private conversation!  If you can live with that you'll have a good time.  Street parking generally available.
author: David P.

description: We had a GREAT experience at Bacco this past weekend.  We dined there early with our 2 kids (age 2 and 4).  We are all gluten free because our daughter has celiac disease and they were knowledgeable and accommodating in every way. They know their menu and had gf bread and gf dessert options.  Highly recommend for anyone who needs to be gluten free and anyone else.
author: Megan Z.

description: Bacco has always been strong on service and a lovely neighborhood place for a meal.  In the last year, the quality of the food has moved from good to excellent.  We've had a series of wonderful meals there.  Some favorites include the sardine appetizer, the rabbit sugo and the wild boar ragu, risottos of the day, and a sensational dessert menu.   The vegetable sides are definitely worth exploring.  We visited this weekend, and there was an amazing butternut squash soup with gorgonzola.
author: Doug G.

description: I love this place.  The waiters are cute and friendly.  The food rocks.  The atmosphere is just about perfect.  Try any of the pastas...fabulous.
author: Kristina R.

description: I don't know why it took me so long to go to Bacco.  Maybe I'm a little jaded with the foodie scene in San Francisco, it is only food after all.
