Several people had encouraged me to try Bacco and my wife and I finally made it last Sunday.  We took our kids and it was great to watch their eyes light up after every bite.  My vegetarian son loved his Sacchetto.  I had the Ghocchi, deep purple from the beets with a gorgonzola sauce. My wife and daughter had two different fish specials.  We finished off with a Tiramisu and a puff pastry that was devoured in about forty seconds!  The service was spectacular and the whole experience was something my kids won't forget.  We were planning our return visit on the way out the door.
author: Diarmuid M.

description: Had the vermicelli with meat balls. The pasta was al dente and the sauce was rich and tangy. The meatballs (3) were generous in size and also tasty. The bread and olive oil was very fresh and virgin with some mint, anchovy, and some other interesting flavorings. Desserts were pricey so I passed. I was quite satisfied with the pasta meal and will definitely return to sample another entree.
author: Eileen M.

description: I just read that the owner of this restaurant is presumed dead. Terrible news. We just dined at the restaurant the night before he went missing. What a great place. I don't have anything negative to say about the evening. The service was very friendly. And it didn't hurt that our waiter was a young handsome Italian with a sexy accent. The food was authentic and delicious. Loved the burrata and the norcino appetizers. The pasta is wonderful. I'm not usually a lamb fan but the pappardelle is delicious. The tomato lamb sauce is to die for. The gnocchi is also pretty perfect. It's so light and the fontina cheese sauce is just right with a hint of truffle. Another delicious choice is the rigatoni. And I never leave without dessert. The puff pastry apple tart is the perfect ending.  I will be very sad if this restaurant closes.
author: Nicole F.

description: At Bacco, the appetizers are a bit hit-or-miss, I've never bothered to order a meat entree, and the desserts are just okay. What they consistently have, by far, is the best pasta and risotto I've ever tasted (including my travels in Italy). They make it in-house, and they cook it perfectly al dente every time. That's why you come here, and that is what you order when you eat here. You won't be disappointed.
author: D V.

description:
Way way way way overpriced.  I got the fixed price menu: the salmon was quite ordinary, the salad smallish and dull, and the chocolate flourless cake not as good as starbucks.  Try paseo or farrina instead. Oh, and the service  very bad even though we were one of only a few people there.
However, I have to give credit to the restaurant for writing to me after giving a bad review!  They claimed to remember me, and they said that I had not complained about the food.  This is true: there was nothing "wrong" with the food in the sense of being cooked badly or the wine having turned.  The food simply was very unimaginative, unflavorful, and of unimaginative quality and presentation.  This was once a decent restaurant -- even a good one -- but it appears to be another case of penny wise and pound foolish.  They seem to be trying to save money by simply cutting the quality of ingredients.  The salad was particularly mediocre in this regard, and the fish was as well.  
It's a little insulting that I would get an email after the bad review, but no offer to try another meal!  As I said penny wise and pound foolish: go to poesia or, if you can get in, Farina or Delfina.
author: clark f.

description: Screw north beach.  This is where to go for some great italian food. The decor could be a little more charming but the gnocchi and the waiters make up for it. Go the whole hog and have tiramisu for dessert. Sing along with me: "I'm in heaven, I'm in heaven"...
author: Simon R.

description: I can't say enough nice things about Bacco. I've been going here off and on for 10+ years. The food is consistently fresh and well-prepared and the staff is great. I can't believe that it's not mobbed nightly...and I can't believe that I'm writing this review and telling everyone about it.
author: Cameron C.

description: A small neighborhood trattoria that excels at everything it does. As already noted, both the risotto and gnocchi, neither an easy dish to perfect, are outstanding. And the tiramisu, that most overdone of Italian desserts, is divine. Consistent in that it never disappoints. Mangia!
author: Gourmet G.

description: After a lot of Yelp searching I chose Ristorante Bacco for my boyfriend's birthday dinner. I had high expectations, but unfortunately they were not met. The food was fine, but it was nothing extraordinary. Likewise the ambiance was ok, but we would have preferred something homier and cozier. With so many other restaurants to try, I doubt we'll be back.
author: K M.

description: My poor DH has wanted to go to Bacco 4ever but I can't do gluten so he was out of luck until tonight. SF Chron ran an article about gluten-free dining in San Fran and Bacco was on the list, so we wasted no more time in checking it out. The food was so good that I thought the DH would keel over dead from joy. Oh, and gluten-free pasta at Bacco? I couldn't tell the difference... and was finally able to have my beloved putanesca after many years w/o it. Swoon. Not hard to see why this appears at the top of so many SF "favorite restaurant" lists. It is now ours too. Oh, and the service -- charming, like you are eating with your extended family in Italy.
author: Cydney B.

description: Ahhhh, San Francisco and its quaint neighborhood trattorias.  Most cities have but one or two; we have them on so many corners, cable car lined streets, and tucked into narrow spaces on narrow alleyways.  This one is quite a pleasant surprise I must say; great service, ambiance, food is excellent.
author: Rick H.

description: I have Celiac's so when my sister was visiting from out of town, we went to the City and wanted Italian food, I googled Gluten Free Italian. This is one of the first to pop up. So we went for it, and it was worth it!!! Oh my goodness, at first I was unsure, cause I don't try new things often. I had the Rigatoni with Gluten free pasta.... all I can say..Is that I was nearly in tears eating it.. It was DELISH! The portion size was good I had some left overs. The Gluten free bread was really good dipped in the pesto/oil, it crumbles if you try and put butter on it. Oh by the way the waiter we had was pretty cute and his accent made him even cuter ;) I would absolutely recommend this to anyone, even kids (there were kids there when I was there) The prices were reasonable, especially since the food was so yummy. Just go you'll LOVE it.
author: Becky B.

description:
This is a true Noe Valley neighborhood gem. Very warm atmosphere and amazing, friendly wait staff and manager! 

The food is excellent. I often start with their Bacco salad and have the lamb chops, done perfectly and as requested. The menu changes regularly for the fresh fish or meat dish. I do love the salmon, and it's prepared simply and well, when it's on the menu. Since I don't know much about the Italian wines, they are great about recommending excellent ones that accompany the dinner. 

Baccar is a place I've taken friends, family and business colleagues. All loved it for it's neighborhood charm and food.
author: Peggy G.

description: This place is terrific.  The food is very good (the apple tart is possibly the best dessert in the City) and the staff is genial.  Despite the suburban decor, this is the real deal.
author: Scott W.

description: Really cozy, cute restaurant.  Had dinner here on Sat. night and had a great time.  I liked the rosemary garlic olive oil they serve with the bread -- such a great idea and I wish more places did that.  We started with the burrata, which came with parma ham, olives and arugula -- delicious.  I ordered the papardelle with a tomato lamb sauce (chunks of tender lamb vs. a ragu).  Also delicious.  BF had the gnocci with truffle oil, which he seemed to enjoy.  Service was excellent.  The server was also very generous with the cheese and fresh pepper -- I wish all italian restaurants were like that.  Will definitely dine here again!
author: Mitzi C.

description: I think I would give this 4.5.  I just can't get myself to give a 5.  I mean "as good as it gets".   Maybe I am too literal but as good as it gets can only come around once in a while and I just haven't found that yet.... Although Bacco is the closest to ever come to a five for me.  The service was great.  The wine they recommended was delicious. As others have recommended you must order the risotto. Seriously, I wanted to take the risotto home and do dirty things with it.  Completely freaking amazing.
author: Roberta J.

description: This place is great. The food is very, very good. Cozy neighborhood type atmosphere. The only complaint I have, if this is one, is that it would be great to have a wine list that stands up to the food. I don't need a bible sized list, just something with some good italian wines on it.  We have only been to this place once, but it is the type of restaurant that you walk out of questioning why you have not been there before.
author: Jason G.

description: Simply charming neighborhood restaurant tucked away in the back of Noe Valley. For an intimate dinner with excellent, traditional Italian food, this is your place. Service is very friendly and attentive, and food is delicious.
author: Aaron L.

description:
people, i don't generally give out 5 stars, so listen up! the food here is fantastic. i ordered a veal stew that was DELICIOUS, and my lovely date for the evening ordered a steak dish with a balsamic reduction that was tres bien! our appetizer was a simple crostini with a bean puree spread topped with sauteed kale, and it was yum-o. dessert was light and refreshing, and even the coffee was great. 

5 stars, firm.
author: eve l.

description: Had clams pasta (i dont know how to call that pasta-the one that they put in pastina soup) and spagetthi with prawns and pancetta.  Fresh pasta.   Service was fast and very attentive.  Awesome calamari stuffed with beans puree-delicious.  Still Delfina is more of my favorite, but this is a great neighborhood Italian restaurant!
author: Saori O.

description: Finally, an Italian restaurant that does not deal out dishes with a heavy hand of salt.  The tomato bread soup is umami heaven.  The bread on the table is nutty and hearty.  Pasta perfectly cooked.  The apple puff pastry with gelato is amazing.  I liked it a lot, maybe as much as Delfina.
author: K W.

description: Best Italian in Noe area. Simple, fresh and tasty. Everything is great. Friendly Italian staff and nice Italian wines. A quiet neighborhood gem.
author: Peter H.

description:
Bacco is the cozy, neighborhoody kind of restaurant that everyone wants around the block from them. Prices are a little higher than I'd like (~$7.50 for salads and $15 for pasta), but with the dearth of decent and flavorful Italian food these days, I'll take it. 
I sampled the Bacco salad which consisted of radicchio, arugula, gorgonzola, walnuts and balsamic vinaigrette. It was simple, the cheese was top notch, strong and ripe enough but not over powering, but overall, was not a salad that I would drive across town for.  I had the gnocchi w/ lamb sugo. The lamb sauce was good, the meat not too dry, and gnocchi themselves were the stars of the plate. They were very tender and lighter than the gnocchi that come out of my kitchen, yum. I also tried a dish with small roasted clams and small grain sized pasta in a brothy tomato saffron sauce. This was surprisingly flavorful. A few of the clams were gritty ( a bit unappealing in an establishment in this price range) but I would order this again. Also tried some raviolis with a brown butter sauce. The raviolis were a smaller but adequate portion while the other 2 dishes were more than enough. 
Overall, a comfortable place with attentive service and simple hearty fare. I would like to see more options in the lower price range of light red wines on their list. I think we split the lightest and cheapest red which was about $36. If possible, I would give it 3.75 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: Having been to several really good Italian restaurants, I had high hopes for Bacco.  Outside of the great service, we were a little disappointed.  The food didn't live up to the hype that  we heard.  The seared duck was a bit over cooked and the two dishes we ordered were served with batchoy (Asian vegetable)?  It didn't seem right for some reason.  I did enjoy the desserts (the apple thing and the espresso with gelato) and the freshness of the pasta in a few of the dishes we tried.  Go there for strictly pasta dishes and you'll be alright.
author: Jason A.

description:
Of all the Italian restaurants in Noe Valley, Bacco fairs well among the pack, but suffers the same syndrome plaguing other places: inattentive waiters. 

That is not to say Bacco is a terrible place. The decor is nicely done -- a combination of dim lighting, wooden rustic chairs, and spongy yellows walls create the perfect mood for intimate dining. But, at times, the table set-up is a little too personal, since seating is squashed tightly together. Hearing loud conversations two tables down is a jarring reminder that anything you say will reverberate clearly off the walls. In the future, let's hope Bacco pries open some elbowroom for the comfort of their guests.  

Inspired by the cuisine of Northern Italy, Bacco's menu boasts a healthy selection of pasta and meat dishes. Braised lamb, seared chicken, gnocchi, porkchops -- all the standard American-Italian dishes you've come to love is priced affordably, ranging from $15 for pasta to $35 for beef dishes. But judging from the reviews posted near their front door, what people really love is their made-to-order risotto. A painstakingly tedious process, risottos take anywhere from 25 to 40 minutes, its ingredients demanding a fastidious chef to stir constantly, ensuring the rice doesnt burn. On their menu, a little disclaimer warns that the risotto isn't a fast dish, but a dish that requires at least thirty minutes to prepare. Incredulously, when I received my risotto, it took not the minimum time, but a short 15 minutes! Perhaps it's not made-to-order, after all.  Sadly, the risotto wasn't as tasty as the reviews claimed. The rice was soft and moist, but lacked the necessary flavor to pull my attention. There's a bit of TLC in there, but it needs more work to live up to its hype. At least the bread and gnocchi was good!

The waiters and the host, though, need a lot of improvement. Slow to meet our needs, our waiter was consistently lazy and absent from the table. It took us a long time to make our order and to close the check. Plus, he botched our order of espresso, forgetting to include it with the desert. When we had asked the host to give us more olive oil, she kindly nodded with a gesture of acknowledgement, then walked away.  Ten minutes later and still no oil. Bacco wasn't even bustling with activity, so there should be no excuse for this type of poor service! To its credit, only the bus boy was helpful, often coming to the table pouring drinks and asking if we needed any help. The tip we left should be given to him, not the waiter.

I wouldnt go out of my way to eat at Bacco again. While the food is somewhat satisfying, the wait staff murders any desire to go back.
author: Richard L.

description:
great prix fix on weekdays, pasta was made fresh, 5 stars!
service is excellent!
author: Pug P.

description: Although a little pricey, the food is delicious and extremely well executed.  My wife had the risotto special with lobster mushrooms and it was the best risotto I've ever had.  I had the wild salmon (how do you pass up fresh wild salmon??) with heirloom tomatoes and it tasted extremely fresh and was seasoned perfectly.  The burrata is an excellent choice for an appetizer.  I had the tiramisu for desert and it was good, but not as rich and creamy as I would have liked...my wife had the affogato al caffe which was delicious.
author: Michael S.

description: I am not one that likes going out to eat pasta. Ristorante Bacco is the exception. This place has never disappointed me. The entrance can get super stuffy with the big curtains and the consistent cluster of 15 people waiting to get seated so that is kind of a bummer. Otherwise, the pasta dishes are some of the best I have had outside of Italy and I have made this my rainy day comfort food go-to.
author: Mia T.

description:
Amazing food. Simple, traditional, dishes prepared perfectly. 
The gnocchi is unusual and amazing, large (5 in an order) and delicate, some of the city's best comfort food. 
Do not miss the: SFOGLIATINA DI MELE CON GELATO (Puff Pastry Apple Tart w/Vanilla Gelato & Caramel Sauce)
There may be deserts in this world which are this good, however you will never find better...
author: Justin L.

description: Absolutely the best italian food in SF. The gnocchi were little pillows of joy and the Italian wine delicious.
author: Shannon B.

description: We did take out so can't speak for service but we did like the atmosphere of the place while we were there to pick up. But the FOOD, oh the FOOD!!!  My seafood-loving boyfriend ordered Fregola "sarinian fregola with fresh clams, mussels, prawn, scallops, tomato & saffron" and I ordered the Rigatoni w/ "tomato, cream, homemade sausage, bell peppers and peas."  My rigatoni was the perfect comfort food, not too creamy or heavy and just delicious. But the gem of the night was the fregola! I am not much into seafood, esp mussels and clams but the way all that flavored the "Sardinian cousin of couscous" was AMAZING! Apparently, fregola (FREG-o-la) is made from semonina mixed with water, formed into pellets and dried. It is a grain and looks kinda like poofier corn kernels or giant couscous grains. But whatever it is, it was DELICIOUS and I could not stop eating my boyfriend's dish!  We can't wait to go back and try a new dish, AND FREGOLA AGAIN!!!
author: Barndi K.

description: Nice place in Noe Valley. I prefer Firefly nearby. Cute restaurant, food ok. Can't quite give a 4th star.
author: Cathy S.

description: This place is good, but 5 stars good?  Yelp is, luck much of our nation, suffering from grade inflation.  Bacco is a solid Italian restaurant, its gnocchi is delicious.  But a better local choice is Delfina.
author: Des Esseintes I.

description: I love this place. My boyfriend and I come here once a month. Great food and great service. The manager and host are all friendly.. Highly recommend!
author: Russell T.

description: Authentic Italian eatery in Noe Valley with great Italian staff that keeps me coming back.   They make fantastic homemade bread, pastas and Tiramasu.  Some of my favorite choices:  crostini bread with fave beans, gnnochi with tomato and mozarrella sauce, papardelle with bolognese sauce and ricotta cheese and any of their fresh fish specials.  Go and enjoy!
author: Michelle M.

description: Very very high quality Northern Italian food with a delightful staff,
author: Bleep S.

description: Great ambiance...romantic, quiet, cutesy little place. The staff is very attentive. The food is delish - no red sauce out of a can here! Great for special occasions or to make any occasion special. Well worth the time and quite a bit better than spending time with tourists in North Beach.
author: Sherie R.

description: Fantastic service with a very mellow atmosphere.  My friend had the gnocchi special for the day...which was incredible.  I had the sea bass, which was super tender and fantastic.  Overall, the bill was around $50 for the two of us...not bad for having a good meal in SF.
author: Mark D.

description: Went there for an early mothers day dinner and the food was impressive. The flavor of the food was just the way I like it, not too strong. With a three person party, we had the Pollo, Vitello, fagiolini arrabbiata, and their special of the day tuna and salmon. Even though to me the dishes seems a tad bit small at the beginning (I do eat a lot), but by the end of the the meal, the amount was perfect. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and love to come back again. Oh with antipasti, a glass of wine, and desert, our bill came out to be $110 (before t&t). Not bad...
author: Derrick L.

description: 2.5 stars but generously rounding up to 3.  Another one of those neigborhood gems that has lost its luster (maybe it can get it back).  The warm faux Italianate interior is still charmng but the food is mediocre and the service indifferent.  The salumi starter was not bad but the fish special was like from a school cafeteria, including the tasteless veggies.  Dinner for two around $100 can be spent elsewhere for a better overall experience.
author: Yan L.

description: Bf and I went here for their prix fix NYE menu and were sorely disappointed. I liked the feel and atmosphere of the restaurant, but the food and service were seriously lacking. Our waiter was downright crappy. He didn't make any effort whatsoever to make us feel welcome in the restaurant. As for the food, I had a salad which tasted like nothing, and a mediocre stuffed duck. My entree came with soft polenta and it had already formed a skin on it by the time they brought it to the table, yuck. The best part of the meal was the chocolate and amaretto cake and the tasty bottle of Turlo Sangiovese we ordered. We won't be back.
author: Kate P.

description: Risotto and gnocchi lovers unite - this place has perfected two of the most temperamental dishes in Italian cuisine.  The flavors change according to seasonal availability, but every rendition has been fantastic so far.  This Noe Valley gem is simply sensational.
author: Alice C.

description: I'm giving one bonus star for being a nice, chill place to linger and talk.  We went to dinner here last night with a group of my old high school pals.  The environs were perfect for chatting and catching up, but I was not terribly wowed by the dinner.  I mean, I did finish everything put in front of me (carpaccio, a tomato-proscuitto pasta dish & tiramisu).  It wasn't that anything was bad; it just didn't knock me over.  Comfortable.  The price could've been a little more comfortable all things considered.
author: Pamela D.

description: I went there for my birthday in Nov this year. The food was great! Their cured meet appetizer plate was so good and I've never found anywhere else serve fresher salumi in town. The waitress was so friendly. Their gnocci was very tasty. I would love to go back to that place again!
author: Yina M.

description:
great food and atmosphere - not too noisy and had an authentic Italian feel.

the stuffed quail was out of this world and the home baked bread was delicious. some of  the people in our party complained because of small portions. 

the pannecotta and tiramisu were excellent.

it's on the expensive side especially if you add the wine, but for a special occasion - it is well worth it.  

Some one is really cooking away in the kitchen and you can tell.
author: Jippers C.

description: Called ahead for 4 of us on a Friday night and got in at 8pm. It was busy in the restaurant and a little tight on space, but seated right away, nice decor and not noisy.  Service was good and fast, appetizers were good too.  The food was great -- we had the rissoto, baby lamb chops, the steak, and pork tenderloin.  Just the right amount of food and cooked perfectly.  I cleaned my plate!  We shared the apple tart for dessert -- really tasty but not much apple but it was okay because it still tasted gooood!
author: Amy H.

description: Mmmmm, is all I can say.  My friend was telling me how good their food was, and I finally got to try it in June.  I followed my friend's recommendation and had squid ink pasta (I'm sorry I don't know the official name).  SO GOOD! Simple and yet flavorful.  Whenever I go to a new restaurant, I have to try their dessert too, and Bacco had pretty good dessert....(drool)  It's a shame I can only go there when I visit SF.  The only reason I gave 4 stars and not 5 is because I've only tried one dish, but I'm sure it's worth 5 stars.
author: Kaoru W.

description: Wam, friendly, well decorated and I assume authentic in its food.  Bacco is always reliable for a good meal in a comfortable, elegant environment.  The fresco mural is a bit kitschy and I wish they had food that wasn't soo rich in olive oil, cheese and butterfat.  It is delicious to go there as a treat.  Too much of this and I'll have to let my pants out.  The Max's restaurants like Max's Opera Cafe have twin signs on their doorposts "This is a bad place for a diet" & "This is a good place for a diet."  Bacco is only a bad place for a diet ;)
author: Francois T.

description: I went here for the first time the other day, and I was pleasantly surprised. The food is hella good, and the ambiance is very nice. In spite of it being a nearly full house, it was quiet, and the lighting was good. The service was quick and unobtrusive, although I felt like our waiter could have been friendlier. They are definitely lacking in vegetarian and non-red meat options, but other than that this place is pretty quality.
author: Aly S.

description: This was close to a four, but not quite there. The food didn't really seem that authentic nor cutting edge. Kind of a tweener, which was not a very memorable experience. The most memorable thing was the creepy old waiter and the absolutely horrendous bottle of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo that I unfortunately purchased. It made me think "why would they put something this bad on their wine list?"
author: Berg W.

description:
Clover, if you had bothered to stop and ask anyone on Diamond Street, you would have found out that Bacco did not have the trees removed, it was their landlord.  

It's a shame you jumped to a false conclusion and trashed an otherwise wonderful restaurant and the equally wonderful people who own it and those that work there.
author: Jim P.

description:
Great vibe, great food. The restaurant has a small dining room, with dark yellow colored stucco walls that set the atmosphere. The staff is super-friendly and their Italian accents help promote the authenticity of this place. But, more importantly, the food is fantastically rich and the olive starter bread is tasty! 

Go here for a cozy, authentic Italian dinner in a quiet, secluded neighborhood.
author: Will C.

description: BACCO BACCO BACCO  such a great place , try the pappardelle  with lamb sauce  it is just a perfect example for a perfect dish served at ur table just perfeeeeeeeeeeeect !!!  if u want a  good antipasti try the bresaola PLZ  DOOO
author: NAEL K.

description: Bacco has had consistently good food and wine every time I eat there.  My favorites are the gnocchi with rock shrimp in a pesto sauce and any risotto they make, but my boyfriend has had excellent chicken and beef dishes here as well.  I love the chianti classico as a wine choice to pair with my pasta.  The ambiance is warm and inviting and the location is easy to get to and has ample street parking-definitely a plus!  Tonight I had their warm apple tart with vanilla gelato and caramel sauce that was delicioso and so is their tiramisu.  Don't miss out on this wonderful place; it really is a gem.
author: Stephanie K.

description: This place is just ok. Ok ambiance, Ok service, just ok food. I had the rigatoni which was ok. I like Lupa better which is just right up the street.
author: julie q.

description: Food was really delicious and the host was very friendly. It was  Friday on the late side of things (8.30) that we arrived so my only complaint is that the service was not very well organized. We had no pepper or parmesan  for our pasta, they overcharged us in the bill. Food was good. Service could have been better.
author: Lupe M.

description: Overall a great restaurant, one of the best in Noe Valley.  I sampled all the food in our three person party and nothing wowed me especially.  But nothing disappointed.  Great authentic Italian staff with a great knowledge of all the food and wine they serve and a nice intimate atmosphere.  Next time I'll bring a date instead of my parents.
author: Nick D.

description: We have gone back twice already, since we discovered Bacco from the PBS show, "Check please, Bay Area." Each dish we ordered got at least 4 stars. It's wonderful to have good quality food in a neighborhood restaurant. If I have to be picky, then I would say that no grappa in the wine menu is a pity for an Italian restaurant!
author: Kan K.

description:
I am relatively new to Yelp.  I've read other people's complaints about "rating inflation" and this restaurant is an excellent example.  The food is just average; it's expensive for what you get; and the service is just so-so.

Tonight we were a group of 4.  We're all (amateur) cooks ourselves.  We all like to eat well and don't mind paying a premium for an excellent meal.  Two in our party had the risotto, which was pretty tasteless.  One person had the mahi mahi special.  The fish was so overcooked as to be unrecognizable.  My braised boar on polenta was the only tasty main course, but it was no better than the braised beef I can do myself.  The appetizers were similarly disappointing.

The service was enthusiastic but amateurish.  The waiter cleared 3 of the 4 appetizer plates before the last person had finished.  Then, the next instant, he appeared with the main courses.  The person still working on her appetizer had to shove it aside to make way for her main course.  We felt like the waiter couldn't wait to get rid of us so he could go home.  (The place was only half full.)

I noticed on the way out that Ristorante Bacco was awarded a plaque for being one of the 100 best restaurants in San Franciso in 2004.  I'm not sure it's in the top 500 now.

The bill, including tax, tip, and wine (but no dessert) was $240 for 4 people.  For that money you could have an excellent meal at Firefly, around the corner.  Next time I want to go out to eat in Noe Valley, that's exactly what I'll do.
author: Jim B.

description: This is my go-to Italian restaurant in SF... delicious food, friendly staff, never a crazy wait, and reasonable street parking. All around winner!!
author: L T.

description: really good spot if you are craving italian. went their last night. . .didn't have to wait for a table--thank god--i was light-headed! very sweet greeting from a modelesque hostess---server brought bread asap! LOVE YOU!!! had a fantastic glass of negroamaro---so smoothe! we started with the calamari and white bean puree--OMG! and the bruschette with kale and picorino--lovely!! i had the gnocchi with gorganzola cream sauce. . . it was amazing! the bf had the penne with sausage. over-all, a fantastic dining experience. cute ambiance. i will return!
author: mary c.

description: Wow...such a disappointment. Tough lamb shank, oily and bland trout. Too bad...
author: Tonya M.

description:
I hadn't been back here in over a year.  

And knew instantly when I walked in with my 2 girlfriends, that Bacco needs to be a regular stop in this City filled with choices.

Bacco is at once an easy to approach neighborhood spot, but also one with sophistication in cuisine, and one where the chatter between the gorgeous red-headed Italian hostess and Italian waiters and Italian busboys (they're all authentic) makes you feel like you had hopped a plane to a cosmoplitan/sophisticated/yet family restaurant in la bella Italia.

Our favorite waiter Luca had the night off, but when I mentioned his name to the hostess, she was very gracious in saying she would love to pass on my name and greetings to Luca (and at the end of our meal, we were given a wonderful tiramusi compliments of Luca).  

We started with the Burrata appetizer, oozing loveliness of creamy cheese coupled with the bitterness of arugula, smoky sweet and saltiness of prosciutto spiked with a few mini black olives.  Combine that with the wonderfully crusty bread and EVOO and balsamic - we girls were in heaven.

Our main courses included a great grilled calamari stuffed with vegetables, red and golden beet salad with ricotta, the garganella tube pasta special with sun-dried tomaties, shiitakes, olives in a tomato cream.  Carnivore and pasta-hound at heart, tonight I was in  a veggie mood and was rewarded with an amazing trio of brussel spours with pancetta, string beans with anchovies and garlic, and incredible, edible. most stupendous broccoli rabe.  I'd come back just for the broccoli rabe.  

Did we say our waiter was amazingly cute?

I was so happy to be back at Bacco.  I remember one evening when owner Paolo came out with a basket of white truffles.  

We have since moved away to the north side of the City, but tonight's experience has made me realize how very, very special Bacco is - and that we need to be back frequently, and soon.
author: Michaela S.

description: Coming from East Coast "Italian Restaurant Madness" I tended to shy away from Italian Restaurants in SF because it will be tough for me to enjoy.  That being said I truly enjoy Bacco - consistent, decent portions and just plain good.  Not rushed but as with many other SF restaurants, make sure to have your reservations in order.
author: M W W.

description: Very good, fresh pasta. Stuffed, grilled calamari and fava bean crostini were excellent appetizers. Fresh pasta dinners were flavorful and the perfect size portions: tagalini with rock shrimp, spaghetti with meatballs, and rigatoni with sausage. Good neighborhood setting - quintessential San Francisco.
author: Tom D.

description: Last weekend we went to a neighborhood favorite for dinner on the spur of the moment - Ristorante Bacco.  I had one of the specials, the Panko crusted sauteed trout.  It was served on a bed of raw arugula and delicious sliced oranges.  It was fileted so that I had NO bones.  The panko crust was delicious - just the right crunch, and the fish was perfectly butterflied before saute-ing so that I could easily eat the fish without the skin.  The arugula and oranges were the perfect complement to this simple yet delicious dish.  I had it with my favorite Bacco white wine by the glass, La Segreta.
author: margot g.

description:
Great true Italian food. 
A bit pricey.
author: Nadav N.

description:
Finally tried this place out -
Atmosphere was nice, service and food good.

Our server wasn't the friendliest, but he was efficient and I don't suppose I am there to make friends... 

We started with the fava been puree crostino - which was yummy.  They served one to each of us and it was plenty.
Second course the Salmone - which was yummy smoked salmon with a lot of lemon, olive oil & fennel.  It was very good.

Entree - husband had the special risotto which was risotto with I believe four different types of cheese.  It was cooked perfectly and the flavor was great.  However it was just a dish of risotto and could have used some in season vegetable or something.  But he ate it all and he knew what he was ordering, so no complaints.

The reason I am giving the restaurant a 3?  My entree of short ribs, which was really just the rib - hardly and meat and what meat I had was more fat than meat.  The gnocchi that came with it was great.  Although disappointed with the ribs, I would like to try this place again and maybe order pasta which looked very good at the table next to us.  However, so did another order of short ribs that was so loaded with meat you could barely see any bones on their plate...

Dessert - chocolate cake, it was good but nothing spectacular.

Will definitely try again and the little take out place next door was great!
author: Mick ..

description:
We saw Bacco on Check Please, Bay Area and decided to try it out last Monday night with another couple.
The homemade bread and pastas were fantastic. Service was great and we can't wait to try it again.
author: K B.

description:
If your ever in the Noe Valley Area and like fresh homemade pasta's definitely check out Bacco. The pasta was amazing. My fiance and I went there one night and had two appetizers, two main courses and a their tirimasu which was outstanding all under $100.  To top it off we also brought in two bottle's of wine. I know we're wino's. All that was included in the price. Great bang for your buck. Not bad considering how much food we had and how great the quality was.

So if your ever in the mood to escape the North Beach cluster, come enjoy some Bacco.
author: Aaron W.

description:
fugging boyfriend. twas his lame idea to come to Bacco, knowing full well the cuisine is not exactly served in hungry-mansized portions. but noooooo, we should try new things baby, who knows, this may replace our favorite neighborhood ristorante, I did grow up down the block from here. so okay, fine, we try it.

strike one: no bar. and we all know we need our cocktails before dinner. no biggie, we find a couple of choices along 24th St and we each enjoy a few drinks while boyfriend catches up on the college football scores. strike two: the tables are a little small, making it uncomfortable for such a big strapping hulk of a man. I swear I was ready to stab him after he stepped on my Kors wedges for the 28th time. third and final strike: delicate metrosexual portions, which were perfectly suitable for me, but not for the Norse god across from me who needs a flamin buffet table piled to the ceiling with food.

I loved the decor and the whole restaurant is charming. boyfriend doesn't pay attention to such things. as long as an eatery doesn't reek of piss or shit, he is a happy boy. he looks at the menu and right away declares, everything is a la carte. uh-huh, yeah so, it's not a foreign concept to us, it's just that we avoid places like that. if it ain't family-style, we don't partake very often. well the man is quite hungry so he orders 2, yes TWO, apps (salad and calamari). I ordered the exquisite polenta, mmmm, it's a meal by itself. I choose the lamb and boyfriend gets the veal. both dishes were lovely and flavorful (mind you, boyfriend eats half of my plate). tonight was boyfriend's turn to foot the bill but surprise of surprises, he forgot to bring his credit card. darlings, this is not the first time this has happened and it will not be the last. we had a nice bottle of red to accompany dinner and their wine list is by no means meager. or cheap, for that matter. final tally: more than $130 and the Incredible Bulk isn't even full !!! this doesn't mean I will never come back, not at all. but next time I will be with someone with a more normal appetite and less of a hippo stomach.
author: Prima D.

description: My sympathy and prayers go to the family.  Very nice family.  Both Sherry and Paolo were very kind when I met them.  And as always, the food at Bacco's is yummy.  I haven't had a bad experience yet.
author: Annette D.

description: Great place.  Fantastic atmosphere perfect for families and couples alike.  I've been coming here since it opened.  We've celebrated many family events there, and the all italian staff and owner get along famously with my 'nonna' who doesn't speak English.
author: B B.

description: I been going to Bacco since they opened 15, 16 years ago. This is a one of best Italian food in San Francisco,  never had any bad food or the service at Bacco. My husband orders Rigatoni every time we are there which he claims to be the best pasta in whole world. We love everything about Bacco and will keep going there as long as they serve good food and wine.
author: Kim M.

description: I have eaten here twice in the last month.  The food was very good and the desserts are great.  Family atmosphere and service was excellent.  Parking is even easy for the area.  Nice menu that changes with the season.  I will be back.
author: GREG C.

description: excellent service and awesome food...I can't understand why anyone would discount this place....portion size was just right! and the desert fabulous.....AAA in my book!
author: candice m.

description: We took a couple of friends to Bacco this week, after not having been there for quite some time.. It was really exceptional.  I can't say enough about the gnocchi, which is made fresh on-site, and the amazing Puff pastry apple tart w/vanilla gelato & caramel sauce that I can't stop thinking about. The Bacco salad was perfectly dressed, the bread outrageously good, and the dipping oil unlike any I've tasted (unlike in a very, very good way!) The ambiance was perfect and the service wonderful.  We'll be back for another special occasion for sure.
author: Gail V.

description: i love bacco.  their pastas are delicious, the service is friendly, you can usually get a reservation, their wine list is great, and they have a fabulous selection of really good desserts.  we were there last friday and had the polenta appetizer with mushrooms and fontina cheese and it was one of the best things i've had all year.  their rigatoni pasta with sausage and peas in tomato cream sause is unbelieveably good.  and their panna cotta dessert (mango & raspberry) melts on your mouth.  seriously - in a neighborhood that has a lot of really good italian restaurants, bacco is right up there at the tip top of the list.
author: Erin C.

description: it was good, but the recommended risotto was a bit bland.  it was good, but not my thing.  everyone else loved their food.  i was being made fun of b/c i was adding salt to my food, which i never do unless i have fries.  the dessert was great and the service was great.  i'll be back.
author: Scott Y.

description: now we're talking. i don't ever choose italian since i don't eat pasta, but mom wanted to eat here so we went last night. it was fairly packed on a monday and i noticed they got a michelin star too! this was a great experience: great service (HOT milano server), great wine, lovely setting, great menu. dishes we sampled: rigatoni (yum), something with house made sausage and peas (yum), steak dish (yum), and i had a salad and polenta (yum, but very cheesy). the tiramisu was great for dessert and i would have loved to have sampled more if i was up to it. they had flourless choco cake and panna cotta too. a very romantic date spot (especially if your date was that hot milano server). will do business again when i feel like going off the gluten wagon.
author: Mary V.

description: This place is amazing! From the service to the food to the atmosphere.  The restaurant is beautiful and the food will have you coming back every time.  The only problem is that if you have to wait there is no where to wait except outside.  Other than that it is a great place to get a good Italian meal.
author: pat j.

description: I almost want to keep this my special secret, but when you find a winner, you just have to share.  And Bacco never disappoints. And that's not an easy thing to achieve.  I have been going to Bacco for years, even rediscovered it at one point, and have found myself drawn to it almost weekly of late.  The food is, in a word, fantastic.  I feel transported back to Italy with their fresh pastas, perfectly balanced sauces and interesting assortment of appetizers, meats and other frequently changing specials.   The only problem I have is pulling myself away from the buccatini amatriciana to indulge in all the goodies!  Bon Appetito...and save me a seat!
author: Jay E.

description: We had a great meal here last night - just what the doctor ordered! We wanted cozy comfort food after a long weekend of drinking and with the cold weather. We'd skipped lunch so we were able to sneak in without a reservation since we were pulling the senior special with a 5:40pm dinner.  The olive oil they bring out with the bread is really delicious, hard to resist. We started with the burrata platter which was fabulous - olives, proscuitto, arugula, and olive oil. It all tasted really rich and fresh. Then my husband had the stuffed breaded veal chop which was so flavorful and perfectly cooked. He cleaned the plate! I had the farro spaghetti dish with bolognese and fresh ricotta. It was really wonderful, exactly what I was craving. We were mentally comparing it to Incanto since we were there last Sunday night, they're both in Noe Valley, and we ordered somewhat similar things. I decided they're tied in my book based on our first two meals - we were super happy with both from environment to food to everything. Also for how fabulous the food was I don't understand comments on it being overpriced here - we were laying off the wine and shared an appetizer, which helped, but all in all with tip we got out of there for $68 I think, and were stuffed and super happy!!! Give it a go if you want original, perfectly made Italian - not the same old lasagna and chicken parm you find at the Mom and Pop places but not the overly California-ized menus you find at places trying too hard to be different!
author: Sarah R.

description: great value, tasty , my go to place , easy to get reservations and good food and good price
author: Peter L.

description: Overrated! I'm not one to bust that label out very often but this is one of those times. I can't count how many good things I've heard about Ristorante Bacco, so I was stunned at how poor it was. At first I was impressed since they seated us right away and the food smelled great. But it went downhill fast! First off nobody took our order for 30 mins, the wine list was small, and the blue cheese on the "Bacco" salad tasted like the Safeway select version. The pasta special was solid if not spectacular as was the stuffed chicken, though the actual meat portion was a little small. The risotto special was so creamy I could feel my arteries hardening as I ate. I'm not a great cook but I can make better risotto than that and with better presentation (though admittedly I have been picking up tips from Food TV). The risotto had a lump of crab meat in the middle and a few sprigs of asparagus. To top it off, the risotto was a steep $30. There's way better homey Italian places in San Francisco so I won't waste my time going back to Bacco.
author: Keith R.

description: Fantastic. Consistently good and reliable. If I crave Italian, I can't think of a better bet that Bacco. You are guaranteed a satisfying experience (a rare statement in this day and age).
author: Nena G.

description: My husband and I chose Bacco for a special New Year's dinner based on Yelp and Trip Advisor reviews, and even though they'd led us to expect a lot, we were more than satisfied. We were initially seated next to a loud family group with little kids -- not our idea of romantic dinner ambiance. When I asked if anything else was available, the owner relocated us to one of the best tables for two in the house, which we greatly appreciated. The service from there on through the server and the person who filled our water and olive oil was worth the five stars alone -- friendly and super-attentive but not intrusive. Our server suggested an excellent and reasonably-priced "Italian Chardonnay" that we both loved. We ordered from the list of New Year's specials: short ribs with gnocchi and tagiolini with Dungeness crab. DH thought the short ribs were slightly fatty but was blown away by the gnocchi; I practically licked my plate clean. The tiramisu was the perfect ending. Overall, we felt that the dishes weren't trying to be anything other than simply great food -- there was a refreshing lack of pretension. The ambiance was warm with just the right lighting for a special dinner a deux, too. Another plus is that the neighborhood is cute, and the walk down Diamond St. to Market, though long and precariously steep in spots, affords some awesome views.
author: Amy G.

description: I ate there this evening.  Their service and presentation is good but I felt my dishes (polenta with wild mushrooms as an appetizer and wild boar as a main) were very underseasoned.  The puff pasty and ice cream desert was excellent.  On the whole, a decent evening though the prices tip a little on the high side given the rather bland two first courses, imo.
author: J. O.

description: I Love Bacco's.  Its always a warm, comfortable, cozy, and friendly atmosphere to dine. The food is Amazing. The Rigatoni is my favorite. I also love the Grilled baby lamb chops  :) Oh , and their  Risotto is so good it melts in your mouth. For dessert The Puff Pastry Apple Tart w/Vanilla Gelato & Caramel , will BE YOUR DESSERT EVERY TIME too.
author: Anna H.

description: I have been dining at this restaurant for a long time. In my opinion, it is the place in SF to eat if you want a high quality Italian dinner cooked in an authentic way at a fair price.  Not cheap but fair.  It is not pretentious. The staff is professional but friendly. They love families and kids. The setting is beautiful and at the same time comfortable.  The  risotto is  incredible. All of the pasta dishes are prepared with care. The fish is super fresh and simply but lovingly prepared. Their best fish dish is  sand dabs. Hard to find in the city. A must if they offer it as a special.  The buratta melts in your mouth. While they will not regularly offer a ceasar salad- as it is not an authentic  italian dish- when they choose to offer it, it is fantastic like all of their  salads.  Fresh. Great flavor. Not over dressed. Their grilled hen is flavorful. Terrific Brussels sprouts!  Very thoughtful and fairly priced wine list. A revelation in SF where most places rip you off on the vino. While all the desserts are tasty, stick with simple: gelato with espresso poured on top. Many places offer affogato, few succeed. Their version is a killer combo. Give this place a try. You won't be sorry.
author: Steve H.

description: I think this is one of San Francisco's most underrated restaurants.  The menu changes frequently and is built around fresh ingredients.  The waiters are Italian and the food is DIVINE.  The gnocchi are fantastic and they are great at recommending wine pairings.  Traditional Italian fare done VERY well.  Not a scene - you can usually walk in and get a table and there is no attitude, just good food and good service in a charming little restaurant.  check it out.

I also like that this restaurant is in a quiet neighborhood, away from the hustle and bustle of North Beach.

description: Simply my favorite restaurant in the City.  Just two of us or on occasion ten of us, service is consistent and impeccable.  Good selection of wine, salads are imaginative, pasta is fresh, meat dishes not too big that you feel stuffed on the way out.  It's as if you've gone to the home of a very, very good Italian chef.  Bravissimo!

description: The food here is great.  I have been there many time and each time I want to come back for more.  The wait staff is very helpful and its a cozy place to bring friends
author: Donna M.

description:
Great dinner!  Intimate little spot in Noe Valley with house-made pasta.  A lot of neighborhood restaurants aren't really destinations worth dealing with the drive, parking, etc...  This place is different.  

I went to Bacco with my girlfriend and another couple.  It was perfect.  Cool waiter with a great Italian accent.  Charming hostess.  And good food.  We had the gnocci with black truffle butter, fregola with fresh clams, mussels, prawn, scallops, tomato and saffron, tonnarelli with tiger prawn, pancetta, porcini mushrooms and arugula, and the risotto, which changes daily.  Mine was with scallops and safron.  I tasted everything.  The gnocci was fluffy and rich.  Fregola also had very good flavor.  I had no idea fregola meant delicious little balls of pasta, but there you go.  The best thing though was probably the tonnarelli.  The only reason this place wasn't 5 stars was my risotto, which was cooked well but a little bland.  After the chowhound reviews I was a little disappointed.  Overall, very good pasta.  Sizeable portions and well-executed flavors.  Will probably not blow you away, but you'll be very satisfied with the meal.  We all were.

For dessert we had the mango and raspberry panna cotta and the tiramisu.  They make all their desserts in-house as well.  The panna cotta was so good my girlfriend slinked back in her seat with that post-bliss smile.  Mmmmm.  Great little spot.  Will go back soon.
author: Josh M.

description: Acceptable food, but very disappointing service at a recent weeknight dinner at Bacco.  After a long wait at the entrance, we were seated at a table that lacked place settings.  Our waiter spoke barely a dozen words to us throughout the meal (none of them "please" or "thank you"), but spent a cumulative half hour chatting with his friends at the next table, standing with his back six inches from our table.  Sorely lacking in professional service to match the (generally good, if pricey) food.
